ولم يقولوا ونقطع أَنْ يُدْخِلَنا رَبُّنا ولم يقولوا إلهنا مع القوم ولم يقولوا مع عبادك الصالحين كما قالت الأنبياء فقال الله لهؤلاء الطائفة التي صفتهم هذه فَأَثابَهُمُ الله بِما قالُوا جَنَّاتٍ محل شهوات النفوس فأنزلناهم حيث أنزلهم الله وقد استوفينا القول في الفرق بين المعرفة والعلم في كتاب مواقع النجوم وبينا فيه إن القائل بمقام المعرفة إذا سألته عنه أجاب بما يجيب به المخالف في مقام العلم فوقع الخلاف في التسمية لا في المعنى ثم حدث لهم في هذا المقام خلاف آخر هل الموصوف به مالك جميع المقامات أم لا والصحيح إنه ليس من شرطه التحكم وأن ملك جميع المقامات بما يعطيه من الأحوال والتصرف في العالم وإنما شرطه أن يعلم فإذا أراد التحكم نزل إلى الحال لأن التحكم للأحوال إذا علم إن نزوله غير مؤثر في مقامه ولهذا لا ينزلون إلى الحال إلا عن أمر إلهي فإذا سمع من شيخ محقق في هذا الطريق إن صاحب هذا المقام مالك جميع المقامات فإنه يريد بالعلم لا بالحال وقد يعطي الحال ولكن ما هو بشرط فإن قال أحد إنه شرط فهو مدع لا معرفة له بطريق الله ولا بأحوال الأنبياء وأكابر الأولياء ويرد عليه هذا القول فإن الكامل كلما علا في المقام نقص في الحال أعني في الدنيا وأما في الآخرة فلا كما أن المشاهدة تغني عن رؤية الأغيار كذلك المقام يذهب بالأحوال لأن الثبوت يقابل الزوال انتهى الجزء الحادي عشر ومائة


( (بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم))


### [إن الله جعل في القوة المفكرة التصرف في الموجودات‏]


واعلموا أن الله تعالى لما خلق القوة المسماة عقلا وجعلها في النفس الناطقة ليقابل بها الشهوة الطبيعية إذا حكمت على النفس أن تصرفها في غير المصرف الذي عين لها الشارع فعلم الله أنه قد أودع في قوة العقل القبول لما يعطيه الحق ولما تعطيه القوة المفكرة وقد علم الله أنه جعل في القوة المفكرة التصرف في الموجودات والتحكم فيها بما يضبطه الخيال من الذي أعطته القوي الحسية ومن الذي أعطته القوة المصورة مما لم تدركه من حيث المجموع بالقوة الحسية فعلم أنه لا بد أن تحكم عليه القوة المفكرة بالتفكر في ذات موجدة وهو الله تعالى فأشفق عليها من ذلك لما علمه من قصورها عن درك ما ترومه من ذلك فخاطبها قرآنا ويُحَذِّرُكُمُ الله نَفْسَهُ والله رَؤُفٌ بِالْعِبادِ يقول ما حذرناكم من النظر في ذات الله إلا رحمة بكم وشفقة عليكم لما نعلم ما تعطيه القوة المفكرة للعقل من نفي ما نثبته على ألسنة رسلي من صفاتي فتردونها بأدلتكم فتحرمون الايمان فتشقون شقاوة الأبد ثم‏


أمر رسول الله صَلَّى اللهُ عَليهِ وسَلَّم أن ينهانا أن نفكر في ذات الله‏


كما فعل بعض عباد الله فأخذوا يتكلمون في ذات الله من أهل النظر واختلفت مقالاتهم في ذات الله وكل تكلم بما اقتضاه نظره فنفى واحد عين ما أثبته الآخر فما اجتمعوا على أمر واحد في الله من حيث النظر في ذاته وعصوا الله ورسوله بما تكلموا به مما نهاهم الله عنه رحمة بهم فرغبوا عن رحمة الله وضَلَّ سَعْيُهُمْ في الْحَياةِ الدُّنْيا وهُمْ يَحْسَبُونَ أَنَّهُمْ يُحْسِنُونَ صُنْعاً فقالوا هو علة وقال آخرون ليس بعلة وقال آخرون ذات الحق لا تصح أن تكون جوهرا ولا عرضا ولا جسما بل عين أنيتها عين ماهيتها وإنها لا تدخل تحت شي‏ء من المقولات العشرة وأطنبوا في ذلك وكانوا كما جاء في المثل أسمع جعجعة ولا أرى طحنا ثم جاء الشرع بنقيض ما دلت عليه العقول فجاء بالمجي‏ء والنزول والاستواء والفرح والضحك واليد والقدم وما قد روينا في صحيح الأخبار مما هو من صفات المحدثات ثم جاء ب لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ مع ثبوت هذه الصفات فلو استحالت كما يدل عليه العقل ما أطلقها على نفسه ولكان الخبر الصدق كذبا إذ ما بعث الله رسولا إِلَّا بِلِسانِ قَوْمِهِ ليبين لهم ما أنزل إليهم ليفهموا وقد بين صَلَّى اللهُ عَليهِ وسَلَّم وبلغ وأشهد الله على أمته أنه بلغ فجهلنا النسبة ب لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ خاصة وفهمنا معقول هذه الألفاظ الواردة وأن المعقول منها واحد بالنظر إلى الوضع فتختلف نسبتها باختلاف المنسوب إليه ما تختلف حقائقها لأن الحقائق لا تتبدل فمن وقف مع هذه الألفاظ ومعانيها وقال بعدم علم النسبة إلى الحق فهو عالم مؤمن ومن نسبها على وجه من وجوه المصارف الخارجة عن التجسيم فلا مؤمن ولا عالم فلو أنصف هذا الناظر في ذات الله ما نظر في ذات الله وآمن بما جاء من عند الله إذ قد دله دليل على صدق المخبر وهو الرسول فهذا منعني في هذا الباب من الكلام في ذات الله بما تعطيه أدلة العقول وعدلنا إلى علم ذلك بما جاء من المنقول مع نفي المماثلة في النسبة والعلم الصحيح‏
بحقيقة الصفة الواردة الموصوف بها ذاتا مجهولة وقد نصحتك فاعلم واثبت على ما جاءتك به الشريعة تسلم فهو أعلم بنفسه وأصدق في قوله وما عرفنا إلا بما هو عليه لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْعَزِيزُ الْحَكِيمُ سُبْحانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ عَمَّا يَصِفُونَ وسَلامٌ عَلَى الْمُرْسَلِينَ والْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ رَبِّ الْعالَمِينَ‏
content.en:
Whoever ascends the steps of Gnosis (المعرفة) sees the attributes within his own soul.
For these attributes point to the One, establishing the distinction between Knowledge (العلم) and Gnosis.
Gnosis has its existence within the existence of the one whom The Real (الحق) sent and did not burden [with the usual obligations].
He is the Imam of the Time (إمام الوقت) in his state, and the seeker desires to know him.
His judgments proceed according to Wisdom (الحكمة) in the high and noble degree.

### [That Gnosis is a Divine Attribute, Unitive in Station, seeking only the One]

Know that Gnosis (المعرفة) is a Divine attribute (نعت إلهي) that has no corresponding Entity (عين) among the Divine Names in its literal form. It is unitive in station (أحدية المكانة) and seeks only the One. Gnosis, according to the People [of Sufism], is a clear path (محجة). Every Knowledge (علم) that is attained only through action, piety (تقوى), and spiritual journeying (سلوك) is Gnosis, because it results from verified Unveiling (كشف محقق) which doubts cannot penetrate. This is contrary to the Knowledge attained through speculative thought (النظر الفكري), which is never safe from the intrusion of doubts, confusion, and questioning the matter that leads to it.

### [Knowledge is not valid for anyone except for him who knows things by his own Essence]

Know that Knowledge (العلم) is not valid for anyone except for him who knows things by his own Essence (بذاته). Whoever knows something through an affair external to his Essence is merely an imitator (مقلد) of that external factor in what it grants him. There is none in Existence (الوجود) who knows things by His own Essence except the One. The knowledge of everything other than that One—whether of things or non-things—is imitation (تقليد). Since it is established that Knowledge of anything is not valid for anything other than God except through imitation, then let us imitate God, especially in the Knowledge of Him.

We only stated that Knowledge of any matter is not valid for anything other than God except through imitation because a human being only knows something through one of the faculties (قواه) God has granted him: the senses (الحواس) and the intellect (العقل). Man must necessarily imitate his senses in what they convey, and they may err or they may correspond to the matter as it is in itself. Or he imitates his intellect in what it grants him, whether through necessity or speculation. The intellect imitates thought (الفكر), which includes both the sound and the corrupt. Thus, his knowledge of matters is accidental (بالاتفاق). There is nothing there but imitation.

If the matter is as we have stated, then the intelligent person, if he wishes to know God, should imitate Him in what He has revealed about Himself in His Books and through the tongues of His Messengers. If he wishes to know things, he should not know them through what his faculties grant him. Rather, he should strive through abundant acts of obedience until The Real (الحق) becomes his hearing, his sight, and all his faculties. Then he will know all matters *by* God and know God *by* God, since imitation is inevitable.

When you know God by God and all matters by God, no ignorance, doubt, uncertainty, or suspicion will enter into that knowledge. I have alerted you to a matter that has not reached your hearing [before]. For the rationalists (العقلاء) among the people of speculation imagine that they are knowledgeable based on what speculation, sense, and intellect have granted them, yet they are in the station of imitating these faculties. There is no faculty whose error they have not already recognized. Despite this, they deceive themselves and differentiate between what the sense, intellect, and thought err in, and what they do not err in. How do they know? Perhaps what they deemed an error is actually correct. There is no cure for this chronic disease except for him whose knowledge of every known thing is *by* God, not by anything else. He, Glory be to Him, is Knower by His Essence (بذاته), not by an external affair. Therefore, you must be a knower of what He knows by Him, Glory be to Him, because you have imitated the One who knows and does not err, and who does not imitate in His Knowledge. Everyone who imitates anything other than God imitates one who is subject to error, and whose correctness is accidental.

If it is said to us: "How did you know this? Perhaps error has entered into these classifications without your realizing it, and you are imitating one who errs—namely, the intellect and thought," we reply: "You speak truly. But since we saw nothing but imitation, we preferred to imitate this one called the Messenger (رسول) and that which is called the Word of God (كلام الله). We relied on this imitation until The Real became our hearing and our sight. Thus, we knew things *by* God and recognized these classifications *by* God. Our correctness in this imitation was accidental (بالاتفاق) because we stated that whenever the intellect or any of the faculties correctly apprehends a matter as it is in itself, it is only by accident. We did not say that it errs in every case; rather, we said we do not know its error from its correctness. When The Real became all his faculties, and he knew matters by God, he then knew the correctness in the faculties from the error."

No one can deny this path we have taken, for he finds it within himself. If this is established, then occupy yourself with fulfilling what God has commanded you: performing acts of obedience, monitoring your heart regarding what occurs therein, having shame before God, observing His limits, seeking solitude with Him, and preferring His presence, until The Real becomes all your faculties. Then you will be upon clear insight (بصيرة) concerning your affair. I have advised you, for we have seen The Real inform about Himself with matters that rational proofs and sound thoughts reject, even while establishing proofs for the veracity of the Informer and the necessity of believing in them. Therefore, imitate your Lord, since imitation is inevitable, and do not imitate your intellect in interpreting Him. Your intellect has already agreed with you on the necessity of imitation by affirming the soundness of this statement that it comes from God. Thus, you have no internal disputant to challenge what you possess. So, do not imitate your intellect in interpretation, but attribute its knowledge to God, the Speaker of it. Then strive until you descend into the Knowledge of Him *as He is*. At that point, you will be a Gnostic (عارف), and that is the sought-after Gnosis (المعرفة) and the sound Knowledge (العلم الصحيح) <<لَا يَأْتِيهِ الْبَاطِلُ مِنْ بَيْنِ يَدَيْهِ وَلَا مِنْ خَلْفِهِ>> (Falsehood shall not come to it from before it nor from behind it).

After this is established, let us return to the customary method in this chapter used by the people of this path, for the method we have alerted you to is an uncommon one. We say that Al-Muhasibi mentioned that Gnosis is the Knowledge of four things: God, the soul (النفس), the world (الدنيا), and Satan (الشيطان). The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said that: Gnosis of God has no path except the Gnosis of the soul. He said: "Whoever knows his soul knows his Lord." And he said: "The one among you who knows himself best is the one who knows his Lord best."

Thus, He made you a proof—that is, He made your Gnosis of yourself a proof of your Gnosis of Him. This is either through the way He described you with the Attributes (صفات) He described Himself with, and His making you a vicegerent (خليفة), a deputy for Him on His earth; or through your state of utter dependence (الافتقار) upon Him for your existence; or necessarily through both matters combined. We see God saying concerning the Knowledge of God, which is expressed as Gnosis: <<سَنُرِيهِمْ آيَاتِنَا فِي الْآفَاقِ وَفِي أَنْفُسِهِمْ حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَهُمْ أَنَّهُ الْحَقُّ>> (We will show them Our signs in the horizons and within themselves until it becomes clear to them that it is The Real). The Real (الحق) thus referred us to the horizons (الآفاق)—which is what is external to us—and to ourselves (أنفسنا)—which is what we are and by which we exist. When we grasp both matters together, then we know Him and it becomes clear to us that He is The Real.

The indication given by God is more complete. This is because if we look into our souls initially, we do not know whether looking at what is external to us in the world—which is His saying, "in the horizons" (في الْآفَاقِ)—grants a Knowledge of God that our souls do not grant, or whether everything is contained within our souls. If we look into our souls, we attain the same Knowledge of Him that the observer of the horizons attains. As for the Lawgiver (الشارع) [the Prophet], he knew that the soul (النفس) encompasses the realities of the cosmos (العالم), so he focused you upon yourself out of eagerness for you, as He said concerning him, <<حَرِيصٌ عَلَيْكُمْ>> (Eager for you), so that the indication might be brought near, and you might swiftly attain the Knowledge of God and be blessed by it. As for The Real (الحق), He mentioned the horizons out of caution for you against what we mentioned: lest you imagine that something remains in the horizons that grants a Knowledge of God which your soul does not grant. So He referred you to the horizons. When you recognize the very indication of God from it, you look into your soul and find that the very thing the observation of the horizons granted you, the observation of your soul also granted you concerning the Knowledge of God. Thus, no doubt remains to enter upon you, because there is nothing there but God, you, and what is external to you, which is the cosmos (العالم).

Then He taught you how to look at the cosmos, saying: <<أَلَمْ تَرَ إِلَى رَبِّكَ كَيْفَ مَدَّ الظِّلَّ>> (Have you not considered your Lord, how He extends the shadow?) [Q. 25:45]... <<أَفَلَا يَنْظُرُونَ إِلَى الْإِبِلِ كَيْفَ خُلِقَتْ>> (Do they not look at the camels, how they are created?) [Q. 88:17] and the rest of the verse. <<أَوَلَمْ يَنْظُرُوا فِي مَلَكُوتِ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ>> (Have they not looked into the dominion of the heavens and the earth?) [Q. 7:185]. In every verse, He requested you to look at the signs (الآيات), as He said: <<إِنَّ فِي ذَلِكَ لَآيَاتٍ لِقَوْمٍ يَعْقِلُونَ>> (Indeed, in that are signs for a people who reason), and "who reflect," "who hear," "who understand," "for the knowledgeable," "for the believers," "for those of understanding," and "for those of intellect." This is because He, Glory be to Him, knew that He created creation in stages (أطوارا), so He enumerated the paths leading to the Knowledge of Him, since each stage cannot exceed its rank based on what God has instilled within it.

The Messenger, peace be upon him, only referred you to yourself because he knew that The Real would become your faculties, and thus you would know Him *by* Him, not by anything else. For He is The Mighty (العزيز), and The Mighty is the one whose sanctuary is inviolable (المنيع الحمى). If anyone other than Him attains Him, His sanctuary is not inviolable, and He is not Mighty. Therefore, The Real became your faculties. When you know Him and attain Him, it is only He who has known Him and attained Him, and the attribute of Might (العزة) is not removed from Him. This is the reality: the door to the Knowledge of Him is necessarily closed except from Him. For this reason, the intellect (العقل) declares Him transcendent (ينزهه) and removes all forms of analogy (المناسبة). Then The Real comes and confirms this with <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). He tells us: "The intellect spoke truly, for it gave what was in its power and knows nothing else. For I gave everything its creation (خلقه), and the intellect is among the things, so We gave it its creation." He completed the verse by saying: <<ثُمَّ هَدَى>> (Then He guided), meaning He clarified. Thus, Glory be to Him, He clarified a matter that the intellect and none of the faculties were granted. He mentioned rulings concerning Himself that the intellect does not accept except through faith (إيمانا) or through an interpretation (تأويل) that brings them under its comprehension—this is inevitable. The path of safety for one who is not upon clear insight (بصيرة) from God is not to interpret, but to submit that matter to God based on His Knowledge of it. This is the path of salvation.

The Real, Glory be to Him, confirms every faculty in what it grants, for it has fulfilled everything God gave it. But there remains for The Real, from the side of The Real, another taste (ذوق) known by the People of God (أهل الله)—who are the People of the Quran, God’s own people and His chosen ones. They believe in every belief concerning Him, for no aspect of anything in the cosmos is devoid of Him, Glory be to Him, and that aspect is the reality of that thing. If the matter were not so, He would not be God, and the cosmos would be independent of Him, which is impossible. Thus, the absence of the Face (وجه) of The Real from anything in the cosmos is impossible. This Gnosis (المعرفة) is difficult to attain, for it leads to the removal of absolute error (الخطاء المطلق) in the cosmos. However, relative error (الخطاء الإضافي)—that which is attributed in relation to its opposite—is not removed. It is an error by opposition, but not an error when opposition is absent. The Perfect One (الكامل) among the People of God is he who looks at every matter individually until he sees the creation (خلقه) that God gave it and fulfilled for it. Then he sees what God clarified for His servants, which is external to the creation of everything. Thus, he places the point of clarification from His saying <<ثُمَّ هَدَى>> (Then He guided) in its proper place, and he places every creation according to what its Creator granted it. Such a person does not err, nor does he err absolutely in principles (الأصول) or branches (الفروع). Every mujtahid (independent jurist) is correct, if you understand, in both principles and branches, and this has been stated [by others].

After what we have mentioned is established, let us say that Gnosis (المعرفة) in our path, when we examined it, we found it confined to the Knowledge of seven things. This is the path followed by the elite (الخاصة) among God’s servants:
1. The Knowledge of Realities (علم الحقائق), which is the Knowledge of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية).
2. The Knowledge of the Theophany (التجلي) of The Real in things.
3. The Knowledge of the address of The Real to His responsible servants through the tongues of the Divine Laws (الشرائع).
4. The Knowledge of Perfection and Deficiency in Existence (الوجود).
5. The Knowledge of man’s soul (الإنسان نفسه) from the perspective of its realities.
6. The Knowledge of Imagination (الخيال) and its connected and disconnected world.
7. The Knowledge of remedies (الأدوية) and ailments (العلل).

Whoever knows these seven matters has attained what is called Gnosis, and what Al-Muhasibi and others said about Gnosis is included within this.

(The First Knowledge) which is the Knowledge of Realities (علم الحقائق), which is the Knowledge of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية). These are of four divisions.

### [The First Division]

The First Division is a division that indicates the Essence (الذات). This is the proper Name (الاسم العلم) from which nothing is understood except the Essence of the Named, indicating neither praise nor blame. We have not found this division among the Names transmitted to us in His Book or upon the tongue of the Lawgiver, except for the Name *Allah* (الله), which is a disputed Name.

A second division indicates the Attributes (الصفات). This is of two types: one that indicates the entities of intelligible attributes (أعيان صفات معقولة) whose existence is possible, and one that indicates relative attributes (صفات إضافية) that have no existence in the entities. A third division indicates the attributes of Acts (صفات أفعال), which is of two types: explicit (صريح) and implicit (مضمن). A fourth division is shared (مشترك), indicating, for example, an attribute of Act in one respect, and an attribute of Transcendence (تنزيه) in another respect.

As for the Knowledge of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية), which is the First Knowledge of Gnosis, it is the Knowledge of what they indicate and for what purpose they came, falling within these divisions we have classified, which we shall clarify in this chapter, God willing. It is also the Knowledge of their specific properties (خواصها). Discussion of this is restricted to the People of God (أهل الله) who possess Gnosis of it, due to the unveiling of secrets (كشف أسرار) and the tearing of veils (هتك أستار) involved, and because Divine Jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية) refuses its disclosure. Indeed, even with their Gnosis of them, the People of God do not employ them against God.

The proof of this is that the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, was the most knowledgeable of people concerning them and concerning God’s response to whoever calls upon Him by them, due to the specific property (الخاصية) they hold in God’s Knowledge of them. Yet, the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, supplicated for his community that God would not make their violence among themselves, and God withheld that from him and did not answer him, although He compensated him in another way. This is because no supplication is rejected entirely, even if the supplicant is punished, but the specific thing supplicated for is rejected if it is requested in a matter that the specific property of that Name does not necessitate. God answered the supplication of Bal'am ibn Ba'ura against Moses, peace be upon him, and his people, when he called upon God by the Name specific to that purpose—which is referred to in His saying: <<آتَيْنَاهُ آيَاتِنَا فَانْسَلَخَ مِنْهَا فَأَتْبَعَهُ الشَّيْطَانُ>> (We gave him Our signs, but he slipped away from them, and Satan followed him). He possessed nothing of the Name except its letters, which he uttered. This is why He said, "he slipped away from them" (فَانْسَلَخَ مِنْهَا); they were on his exterior like a garment on the wearer, just as a snake sheds its skin. Had they been in his interior, modesty and his station would have prevented him from supplicating against a Prophet. He was answered due to the specific property of the Name, yet he was punished and his likeness was made <<كَمَثَلِ الْكَلْبِ>> (like the likeness of a dog), and he forgot the letters of that Name. If the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, had supplicated using the specific Name and employed it, God would have answered him precisely in what he asked, despite our knowledge that he knew the knowledge of the ancients and the moderns, and that he was the most knowledgeable of people. Thus, we know that his supplication was not by the specific Name, and he acted with Divine courtesy (الأدب الإلهي). The reason for this courtesy is that he does not know what is in God’s Self (نفس الله), as Jesus, peace be upon him, said: <<تَعْلَمُ مَا فِي نَفْسِي وَلَا أَعْلَمُ مَا فِي نَفْسِكَ>> (You know what is in my self, but I do not know what is in Your self). Perhaps what he was supplicating for was not good for him. So, they, peace be upon them, turned to supplicating God for what they desired without using the Name specific to that desired thing. If God had pleasure in it in His Knowledge and it was good for the supplicant, He answered precisely what was asked. If not, He compensated the supplicant with degrees or expiation of sins.

It is known by both the elite and the common folk that there is a general Name called the Greatest Name (الاسم الأعظم), which is found in the Verse of the Throne (آية الكرسي) and the beginning of the Chapter of Al ‘Imran. Despite the Prophet, peace be upon him, knowing it, he did not supplicate with it concerning the matter we mentioned. Had he supplicated with it, God would have answered him precisely what he asked, yet God’s Knowledge concerning things is never invalidated. For this reason, God disciplined His people. This is part of the Knowledge of the Divine Names. Some Names are composed of letters, and some are composed of words, such as *Al-Raḥmān Al-Raḥīm* (الرحمن الرحيم), which is a compound Name like *Ba'labak*. And that which is composed of letters is like *Al-Raḥmān* (الرحمن) alone.

### [Properties of Letters]

Know that letters (الحروف) are like natures (الطبائع) and like drugs, indeed, like all things: they have properties (خواص) individually and properties when compounded. Their properties when compounded are not due to their individual entities, but rather to the unitive nature of the combination (أحدية الجمعية). Understand this, so that the only Agent (الفاعل) in the cosmos is the One, for this is a proof of the Oneness (توحيد) of the Deity. Just as He is One and has no partner in His acts upon things, so too has the Reality (الحقيقة) permeated the acts attributed to the existent things (الأكوان): they only issue forth when compounded due to the unitive nature of that composition. Every part of the composition, individually, has a property that contradicts the property of the whole. When two or more parts combine, they produce an effect that none of the individual parts of that whole possesses. For example, the blackness of ink: the blackness arises from the whole due to the unitive nature of the combination, and no individual part produces that blackness. The composition of words is thus like the composition of letters.

From this, you know that a single letter has an effect, but only by intention (بالقصد). For example, the letter *shīn* (ش) in the Arabic language, when heard, implies that he tore his garment (بشّ ثوبه), and it is a single letter. *Qāf* (ق) implies that he protected himself from such-and-such. *Ayn* (ع) implies that he comprehended what he heard, despite being a single letter. As for *Kun* (كن - Be!), it is the act of a single word, not the act of letters, and its specific property is in bringing things into existence (الإيجاد). Despite this, it has conditions, and the People of God (أهل الله) practice courtesy with God, so they substituted it in action with *Bismillah* (In the Name of God). The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, used it in the Battle of Tabuk, but it was not heard from him before or after. He only intended to inform the knowledgeable among the Companions of such secrets through that action.

What we mention in this chapter is the Knowledge of the divisions of the Divine Names we discussed: the Names of the Essence (أسماء الذات) which are like proper nouns (أعلام). I do not know of anything in the hands of the scholars, in a book or Sunnah, belonging to this category except the Name *Allah* (الله), according to the view of those who do not consider it derived from anything. Furthermore, even with the derivation found in it, is it intended for the Named or not? Just as a person is named *Yazīd* (زيد) as a proper noun, even though it is an action of increase (زيادة), we did not name him that because he increases and grows in body or knowledge. Rather, we named him that so we could recognize him and call out to him when we want him. Some Names are established by convention (بالوضع) in this manner. If they are used in this way, they are all proper nouns. If they are used as praise, and they are Names of praise, then they are truly Names of Attributes (أسماء صفات). It is characteristic of an Attribute that its existence is only intelligible within that which is described by it, because it does not subsist by itself, whether it has an essential existence (وجود عيني) or a relative existence (وجود إضافي) that has no existence in its essence. Thus, they indicate the one described by them through praise or blame, and through commendation. In this manner, the Divine Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى) were transmitted in the Quran, and all of them describe His Essence, Glory and Exaltation be to Him, through meaning, while the word *Allah* is through verbal convention (الوضع اللفظي).

### [Names of the Essence and Names of Pronouns]

It is apparent that the Name *Allah* (الله) is for the Essence (الذات) as a proper noun, not intended for derivation, even if it contains a hint of derivation, as some scholars of Arabic grammar hold. As for the Names of Pronouns (أسماء الضمائر), they undoubtedly indicate the Essence and are not derived, such as *Huwa* (هو - He), *Dhā* (ذا - That), *Anā* (أنا - I), *Anta* (أنت - You), *Naḥnu* (نحن - We), the *yā’* in *Innī* (إني - Indeed I), and the *kāf* in *Innaka* (إنك - Indeed You). The word *Huwa* is the pronoun for the absent (الغائب). Pronouns are not exclusive to The Real; rather, they are for every implied subject. It is a word that indicates an absent essence, provided there is preceding speech that indicates it to the listener. If not, it is useless. For this reason, pronominal reference before mention is not permissible except in poetic necessity, due to the constraints of meter upon the poet. An example cited for this is:

May his Lord reward ‘Adī ibn Ḥātim on my behalf
(جزى ربه عني عدي بن حاتم)

He used the pronoun before the mention, because he intended to say: "May ‘Adī ibn Ḥātim’s Lord reward him on my behalf," but it did not fit the meter, so he brought the pronoun forward for the sake of the meter.

Among the pronouns is the word *Dhā* (ذا), which is one of the demonstrative names, such as His saying: <<ذَلِكُمُ اللَّهُ>> (That is God). Likewise, the *yā’* of the first-person singular, such as His saying: <<فَاعْبُدْنِي وَأَقِمِ الصَّلَاةَ لِذِكْرِي>> (So worship Me and establish prayer for My remembrance). Likewise, the word *Anta* (أنت - You) and the *tā’* of the second-person singular, such as His saying: <<كُنْتَ أَنْتَ الرَّقِيبَ عَلَيْهِمْ>> (You were the Watcher over them). And the word *Naḥnu* (نحن - We), the emphasized word *Innā* (إنا - Indeed We), and the *nā* (نا - We/Us), such as His saying: <<إِنَّا نَحْنُ نَزَّلْنَا الذِّكْرَ>> (Indeed, We, We sent down the Remembrance). And likewise, the letter *kāf* of address: <<إِنَّكَ أَنْتَ الْعَزِيزُ الْحَكِيمُ>> (Indeed, You are the Mighty, the Wise). All of these are Names of pronouns, demonstratives, and allusions (كنايات) that encompass every implied subject, addressed person, indicated object, and alluded-to subject, and their like. Despite this, they are not proper nouns, but they are stronger in indication than proper nouns because proper nouns may require descriptions, whereas these do not. There is no word among them that does not yield a result in the remembrance (الذكر) of it. We have not seen anyone among the People of God (أهل الله), the people of spiritual taste (أهل الأذواق), draw attention to this in the path of God for the spiritual travelers (السالكين) through remembrance, except for the word *Huwa* (هو) specifically. They made it the remembrance of the most specific of the specific (خصوص الخصوص) because, in its original convention, it is more definitive than the Name *Allah* to them, as it indicates only the specific implied Entity (العين خاصة) without derivation. The People of God favored it over other implied subjects and allusions because it is the pronoun of absolute absence (ضمير غيب مطلق), detached from the attachment of knowledge to its reality. They said that the word *Huwa* refers to His Ipseity (هويته), which none knows but Him. They relied on this, especially the group that claimed that He does not know Himself—exalted is God far above that! That group did not know that other than the word *Huwa* in remembrance is more complete in rank, such as the *yā’* in *Innī* (إني), the *nūn* in *Nazzalnā* (نزلنا), and the word *Naḥnu* (نحن). These are higher in rank in remembrance than *Huwa* for the spiritual traveler (السالك), though not for the Gnostic (العارف). For the Gnostics, nothing is higher than the remembrance of *Huwa* for their own state. Just as these are higher in rank than the word *Huwa* to them, they are likewise higher than the Names of address, such as the *kāf* of address, its *tā’*, and *Anta* (أنت). For none says *Innī* (I), *Innā* (We), or *Naḥnu* (We) except Him about Himself. So, whoever says them *by* Him, He is the Speaker, and <<وَلَذِكْرُ اللَّهِ أَكْبَرُ>> (And the remembrance of God is greater). Its result is greater because remembrance is magnified according to the magnitude of the knower’s knowledge, and none is more knowledgeable than God. The rest of the Names of Pronouns, such as *Huwa*, *Dhā*, and the *kāf* of address, are among the specific properties of the indicated Entity, so they are more noble than *Huwa*. Despite this, none of the People of God has established the remembrance of them as they did with the word *Huwa*. I do not know if they were prevented from this by the lack of spiritual taste (الذوق) for this meaning—which is the most likely reason—for they did not make them a form of remembrance. If they say that they require definition, we say that this is permissible for all implied subjects. We advocate for remembrance by all of them, with presence, in a specific manner.

There has come in the Divine Law (الشرع) that which strengthens our position on this, namely His saying, peace and blessings be upon him, that God said upon the tongue of His servant: "God hears the one who praises Him." And His saying, related from God: "I was his hearing, his sight, his tongue, his hand, and his foot."

The Real (الحق) is undoubtedly the Speaker using the *nūn* (ن), *Anā* (أنا), *Innā* (إنا), *Naḥnu* (نحن), and *Innī* (إني). So let us remember Him by them, acting as His deputy, or let us remember Him by Him, because He is the one remembering by them upon my tongue. This is more complete in the presence (الحضور) of remembrance and closer to the opening (فتح) for grasping what they indicate. These Names—meaning the pronouns—also have properties in action. I have not seen anyone among the People of God know any of them except the word *Huwa* (هو). When you say *Huwa*, He is *Huwa*. Even if He is not *Huwa* when you say *Huwa*, He will be *Huwa* when you say *Huwa*. The same applies to the rest of the Names of implication. Know this, for it is one of the secrets of Gnosis of God (المعرفة بالله). None of the People of God has perceived it or drawn attention to it, out of jealousy, stinginess, or fear of the prohibition related to the manifestation of God’s creative act (تكوين الله) when the servant utters the word *Huwa*, since God speaks it upon the tongue of His servant. The sign of this is in the Book of God: <<فَتَنْفُخُ فِيهَا فَتَكُونُ طَيْرًا بِإِذْنِي>> (Then you breathe into it, and it becomes a bird by My permission). God’s creative act through the servant’s utterance of *Huwa* is His manifestation in a specific locus (مظهر) at that time, since none but Him manifests, and none said *Huwa* except Him. Thus, He manifested Himself. He is The Manifest (الظاهر), The Manifester (المظهر), The Hidden (الباطن), The Hider (المبطن), The Mighty (العزيز), The Giver of Might (المعز), The Rich (الغني), and The Enricher (المغني). I have alerted you to the secret of this remembrance by this Name. You should apply this to all the Names of pronouns, demonstratives, and allusions. However, purity, presence (الحضور), courtesy (الأدب), and Knowledge of these matters are essential so that you know whom you are remembering, how you are remembering, who is remembering, and by whom you are remembering. God is the best of those who remember Him and you.

(The Second Division) of the Knowledge of the Divine Names. This division is split into two types: The Knowledge of the Names of the Attributes of Meaning (صفات المعاني), such as *Al-Ḥayy* (الحي - The Living), which is a Name that requires an Essence (ذات) described by Life (الحياة). Knowledge (العلم) names the one described by it *‘Ālim* (Knower); Power (القدرة) names him *Qādir* (Powerful); Will (الإرادة) names him *Murīd* (Willer); and Hearing, Sight, and Speech name him *Samī‘* (Hearer), *Baṣīr* (Seer), and *Shakūr* (Appreciative). All of these are meanings subsisting in the described subject, or relations (نسب) upon which Names are based, and they have rulings concerning the one described by them.

Although these Names indicate an Essence described by an attribute called Knowledge or Power, they possess degrees (مراتب). For example, the one in whom Knowledge subsists is called *‘Ālim* (Knower), *‘Alīm* (All-Knowing), *‘Allām* (Great Knower), *Khabīr* (Aware), *Muḥṣī* (Counter), and *Muḥīṭ* (Encompasser). All these are Names for one described by Knowledge, but the meaning indicated by being *‘Ālim* is different from the meaning indicated by being *‘Alīm* or *Khabīr*. From these, one understands what is not understood from *‘Ālim*. *‘Alīm* denotes hyperbole, so one understands from it what is not understood from *‘Ālim*. For one who knows a single piece of information is called *‘Ālim*, but he is not called *‘Alīm* or *‘Allām* unless his Knowledge relates to numerous pieces of information. *Khabīr* (Aware) relates to Knowledge after trial, as He, the Exalted, said: <<وَلَنَبْلُوَنَّكُمْ حَتَّى نَعْلَمَ>> (And We will surely test you until We know). Likewise, *Al-Muḥṣī* (The Counter) relates to the enumeration of information in a valid way; it is a specific relation that Knowledge requires. Similarly, *Al-Muḥīṭ* (The Encompasser) has a specific relation, which is the Knowledge of the realities of information—essential, formal, and verbal—and that which is finite is known as finite, and that which is infinite is known as infinite. He has encompassed it with Knowledge that it is infinite. Here, a large group of scholars stumbled. You should apply this to all Attributes, such as *Al-Qādir* (The Powerful), *Al-Muqtadir* (The Omnipotent), and *Al-Qāhir* (The Subduer); all of these are required by Power (القدرة). There are distinctions (فرقان) between these Names, even though the same Attribute requires them. *Al-Qāhir* is in opposition to a single contender, and *Al-Qahhār* (The Overpowering) is in opposition to multiple contenders. *Al-Qādir* is in opposition to the recipient of the effect, even though it is non-existent in its essence, so there is a kind of impossibility in it. This is a problematic issue, because the precedence of non-existence for the possible thing (الممكن) before its existence is neither willed nor is it an essential attribute of the possible thing. This is the difficulty that must be understood. *Al-Muqtadir* (The Omnipotent) only exists when Power relates to the object of Power (المقدور), because it acts in the relation of Power to the object of Power to bring its entity into existence, like the acquirer (*muktasib*) and the earner (*kāsib*). Thus, the distinctions between the Names have become clear to you, even though they require a single attribute, but in different respects, for synonymy (الترادف) is not valid in the cosmos, because synonymy is repetition, and there is no repetition whatsoever in Existence (الوجود) due to Divine vastness. Know this.

We have not found a Divine Name in the Divine Law (الشرع) for Speech (الكلام) except *Al-Shakūr* (The Appreciative) and *Al-Mujīb* (The Responder). Thus, for Speech, we have not found a Name derived from its own word in the Divine Law. Likewise, Will (الإرادة) has no Name derived from its own word, to my knowledge, except that among its Names, from the perspective of its meaning, are the Names of Acts (أسماء الأفعال), for He said: <<فَعَّالٌ لِمَا يُرِيدُ>> (Doer of what He wills). Will has a relation that is difficult to conceive, which is His willing to speak, yet His speech is not among the Acts, nor is it a non-existent relation, nor a non-existent attribute. The same can be conceived for Power (القدرة), such as when it is said that The Real is Powerful to speak to His servants with whatever He wills. Here is a Knowledge that must be known: God brought the relation of His Will under the ruling of time (الزمان), using *idhā* (إذا - when), which is a temporal particle. He said: <<إِذَا أَرَدْنَاهُ أَنْ نَقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ>> (When We will it, We only say to it, 'Be!'). Time may be added, but *idhā* is not valid in it because it has not yet existed, so it would have a ruling. This is a Knowledge from the obscure sciences of the Divine Names.

Then know that what the People of God (أهل الله) rely upon concerning His Names, Glory be to Him, are those by which He named Himself in His Books or upon the tongues of His Messengers. If we take them from derivation or as a form of praise, their multitude is countless. God says: <<وَلِلَّهِ الْأَسْمَاءُ الْحُسْنَى>> (And to God belong the Most Beautiful Names). It is reported in the *Ṣaḥīḥ* [Hadith collection] that God has ninety-nine Names, one hundred minus one, and whoever enumerates them shall enter Paradise. We have not been able to specify them from an authentic source, for the narrations concerning them are all inconsistent, and none of them is sound.

Every Divine Name that comes to us through Unveiling (الكشف), or to anyone else, we do not record it in a book, even if we supplicate with it privately, due to the corruption it leads to among the pretenders <<الَّذِينَ يَفْتَرُونَ عَلَى اللَّهِ الْكَذِبَ>> (who invent lies about God), and there are many of them in our time. When we searched among the memorizers of Hadith (*ḥuffāẓ*), we found no one who paid attention to them like the *Ḥāfiẓ* Abū Muḥammad ‘Alī ibn Sa‘īd ibn Ḥazm al-Fārisī. The utmost he was able to achieve in enumerating the Beautiful Names from authentic paths is what I shall mention. This is the extent of his enumeration, as narrated to us by ‘Alī ibn ‘Abd Allāh ibn ‘Abd al-Raḥmān al-Firyābī, from Abū Muḥammad ‘Abd al-Ḥaqq ibn ‘Abd Allāh al-Azdī al-Ishbīlī, and ‘Abd al-Ḥaqq narrated it to us by authorization (*ijāzah*), and others, through hearing, reading, and authorization, from Abū al-Ḥasan Shurayḥ ibn Muḥammad ibn Shurayḥ al-Ru‘aynī, from Abū Muḥammad ‘Alī ibn Ḥazm al-Fārisī, who said: "The Names are taken only from the text of the Quran and what is authenticated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him." Our enumeration reached what we shall mention, and they are:

*Allah* (الله), *Al-Raḥmān* (الرحمن), *Al-Raḥīm* (الرحيم), *Al-‘Alīm* (العليم), *Al-Ḥakīm* (الحكيم), *Al-Karīm* (الكريم), *Al-‘Aẓīm* (العظيم), *Ḥalīm* (حليم), *Al-Qayyūm* (القيوم), *Al-Akram* (الأكرم), *Al-Salām* (السلام), *Al-Tawwāb* (التواب), *Al-Rabb* (الرب), *Al-Wahhāb* (الوهاب), *Al-Aqrab* (الأقرب), *Samī‘* (سميع), *Mujīb* (مجيب), *Wāsi‘* (واسع), *Al-‘Azīz* (العزيز), *Al-Shākir* (الشاكر), *Al-Qāhir* (القاهر), *Al-Ākhir* (الآخر), *Al-Ẓāhir* (الظاهر), *Al-Kabīr* (الكبير), *Al-Khabīr* (الخبير), *Al-Qadīr* (القدير), *Al-Baṣīr* (البصير), *Al-Ghafūr* (الغفور), *Al-Shakūr* (الشكور), *Al-Ghaffār* (الغفار), *Al-Qahhār* (القهار), *Al-Jabbār* (الجبار), *Al-Mutakabbir* (المتكبر), *Al-Muṣawwir* (المصور), *Al-Barr* (البر), *Muqtadir* (مقتدر), *Al-Bārī* (الباري), *Al-‘Alī* (العلي), *Al-Ghanī* (الغني), *Al-Walī* (الولي), *Al-Qawī* (القوي), *Al-Ḥayy* (الحي), *Al-Ḥamīd* (الحميد), *Al-Majīd* (المجيد), *Al-Wadūd* (الودود), *Al-Ṣamad* (الصمد), *Al-Aḥad* (الأحد), *Al-Wāḥid* (الواحد), *Al-Awwal* (الأول), *Al-A‘lā* (الأعلى), *Al-Muta‘āl* (المتعال), *Al-Khāliq* (الخالق), *Al-Khallāq* (الخلاق), *Al-Razzāq* (الرزاق), *Al-Ḥaqq* (الحق), *Al-Laṭīf* (اللطيف), *Ra’ūf* (رءوف), *‘Afūw* (عفو), *Al-Fattāḥ* (الفتاح), *Al-Matīn* (المتين), *Al-Mubīn* (المبين), *Al-Mu’min* (المؤمن), *Al-Muhaymin* (المهيمن), *Al-Bāṭin* (الباطن), *Al-Quddūs* (القدوس), *Al-Malik* (الملك), *Malīk* (مليك), *Al-Akbar* (الأكبر), *Al-A‘azz* (الأعز), *Al-Sayyid* (السيد), *Subbūḥ* (سبوح), *Witr* (وتر), *Muḥsin* (محسان), *Jamīl* (جميل), *Rafīq* (رفيق), *Al-Mus‘ir* (المسعر), *Al-Qābiḍ* (القابض), *Al-Bāsiṭ* (الباسط), *Al-Shāfī* (الشافي), *Al-Mu‘ṭī* (المعطي), *Al-Muqaddim* (المقدم), *Al-Mu’akhkhir* (المؤخر), *Al-Dahr* (الدهر).

This is what we have narrated from our Shaykhs, from their Shaykhs, concerning his enumeration. We also have other Names from the Quran that came in an annexed form (مضافة), which we consider Names, but he does not. The same applies to the narrations. Whoever truly wishes to grasp the Names of God, the Exalted, should look at His saying: <<يَا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ أَنْتُمُ الْفُقَرَاءُ إِلَى اللَّهِ>> (O mankind, you are the needy ones toward God). In reality, there are only His Names in Existence (الوجود), but the entities of the existent things (أعيان الأكوان) veil the eyes of insight (عيون البصائر) from the Knowledge of them. For He, Glory be to Him, is The Protector (الواقي) and none other. He is veiled by every protector and its like. He is <<فَاطِرِ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ>> (Originator of the heavens and the earth), <<جَاعِلِ الْمَلَائِكَةِ رُسُلًا>> (Maker of the angels messengers), <<وَجَعَلَ اللَّيْلَ سَكَنًا>> (And He made the night a repose), <<وَجَاعِلٌ فِي الْأَرْضِ خَلِيفَةً>> (And Maker of a vicegerent on earth), and <<نُورُ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ>> (The Light of the heavens and the earth), and the Sustainer of the heavens and the earth. He is *Al-Ṣabūr* (The Patient), <<وَقَابِلِ التَّوْبِ>> (Acceptor of repentance), <<سَرِيعُ الْحِسَابِ>> (Swift in account), <<شَدِيدُ الْعِقَابِ>> (Severe in penalty), <<رَفِيعُ الدَّرَجَاتِ>> (Exalter of ranks), <<ذُو الْعَرْشِ>> (Possessor of the Throne), and *Dhū al-Ma‘ārij* (Possessor of the Ascending Stairways). I have set you upon the path. This is the division of Attributes that indicate meanings, relations, and annexations, such as *Al-Awwal* (The First), *Al-Ākhir* (The Last), *Al-Ẓāhir* (The Manifest), and *Al-Bāṭin* (The Hidden).

(The Third Division) which is the Names of Acts (أسماء الأفعال). These are explicit, like *Al-Muṣawwir* (The Fashioner), and implicit, such as His saying: <<وَمَكَرَ اللَّهُ>> (And God planned). All Names of Acts are Names of Will (الإرادة).

(The Fourth Division) Shared Names (أسماء الاشتراك). Such as His Name *Al-Mu’min* (The Believer) and *Al-Rabb* (The Lord). *Al-Mu’min* means The Confirmer, and *Al-Mu’min* means The Giver of Security. *Al-Rabb* means The Owner, *Al-Rabb* means The Reformer, *Al-Rabb* means The Master, *Al-Rabb* means The Educator, and *Al-Rabb* means The Fixed. When you possess a Divine Name, look at which degree (مرتبة) among these degrees it belongs to, and supplicate by it according to its degree. Do not remove it entirely from its degree, and do not neglect its indication of the Essence (الذات) which possesses all these attributes. Then you will be the unitive Entity (أحدي العين) within the very eye of Multiplicity (عين الكثرة), and thus you will be the One who is Many. For the degrees (المراتب) and realities (الحقائق) require the Names for the one whose attributes they are, so that when He is supplicated by them, they flourish and know that God has concern for them, since He applied Names derived from their rulings to Himself, and since He made His Essence the locus for their rulings. Forbearance (*ḥilm*) is an intelligible meaning from which a Name is derived for the one in whom its ruling appears, namely *Al-Ḥalīm* (The Forbearing), along with *Al-Mutajāwiz* (The Overlooker), *Al-Ṣafūḥ* (The Pardoner), and *Al-‘Afūw* (The Pardoner), all with Power. Likewise, the degree of Generosity (*karam*) is an intelligible meaning from which a Name is derived for the one from whom its ruling appears, such as *Al-Karīm* (The Generous), *Al-Mu‘ṭī* (The Giver), *Al-Jawwād* (The Munificent), *Al-Wahhāb* (The Bestower), and *Al-Mun‘im* (The Benefactor). You should treat all Names in the manner I have indicated to you, and do not let them exceed their degrees, while knowing that there is no synonymy (ترادف) among the Names of God, and that they are all distinct. I have thus clarified for you the First Knowledge of Gnosis (المعرفة) belonging to the People of God, in summary with a portion of detail, so understand this.

The Second Type of the Sciences of Gnosis (المعرفة), which is the Knowledge of Theophany (علم التجلي).

Know that the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) is perpetual and has no veil over it, but it is not known that it is He. This is because when God created the cosmos (العالم), He made it hear His Word while it was in a state of non-existence (عدم), which was His saying *Kun* (Be!). He, Glory be to Him, was witnessed, but The Real (الحق) was not witnessed by it. The veil of non-existence was over the eyes of the possible things (الممكنات); there was nothing else. Thus, the existent thing cannot be perceived while it is non-existent, just as light repels darkness, for darkness cannot remain in the presence of light. Likewise, non-existence and Existence (الوجود). When He commanded them to come into being (التكوين) due to their possibility (إمكانها) and their readiness to accept, they hastened to see what was there, because they possessed the potential for sight, just as they possessed the potential for hearing, from the perspective of immutability (الثبوت), not from the perspective of existence. When the possible thing came into existence, it was dyed with the Light (النور), and non-existence vanished. It opened its eyes and saw Existence (الوجود), which is pure Goodness. It did not know what it was, nor did it know that it was He who granted it existence.

The Theophany (التجلي) granted it Knowledge (علم) of what it saw, but not Knowledge that it was He who granted it existence. When it was dyed with the Light, it turned to the left and saw non-existence (العدم) and verified it. Behold, it emanated from it like the shadow emanating from a person when confronted by light. It asked, "What is this?" The Light from the right side said to it: "This is you. If you were the Light, the shadow would not have an entity. We are the Light, and I am its remover. The light you possess is only from the aspect of your essence that faces Me. This is so you may know that you are not Me, for We are Light without shadow, and you are the mixed Light due to your possibility (إمكانك). If you are attributed to your direction [the Light], and if you are attributed to non-existence, you are accepted. Thus, you are between Existence and non-existence, and you are between good and evil. If you turn away from your shadow, you have turned away from your possibility. If you turn away from your possibility, you are ignorant of Me and do not know Me, for your only proof that I am your God, your Lord, and your Creator is your possibility, which is your witnessing of your shadow. If you turn away from your Light entirely and remain only witnessing your shadow, you will not know that it is the shadow of your possibility, and you will imagine that it is the shadow of the impossible (المحال). The impossible and the Necessary [God] are opposites in all respects. If I call you, you will not answer Me and will not hear Me, for that witnessed thing will deafen you to My call. So, do not look at Me with a gaze that annihilates you from your shadow, causing you to claim that you are Me, thereby falling into ignorance. Nor look at your shadow with a gaze that annihilates you from Me, for that will cause you deafness, and you will be ignorant of what I created you for. So, be sometimes this and sometimes that. God only created two eyes for you so that you might witness Me with one and witness your shadow with the other. I said to you, in the context of granting favor: <<أَلَمْ نَجْعَلْ لَهُ عَيْنَيْنِ * وَلِسَانًا وَشَفَتَيْنِ * وَهَدَيْنَاهُ النَّجْدَيْنِ>> (Have We not made for him two eyes, and a tongue and two lips, and guided him to the two highways?) [Q. 90:8-10]. That is, We clarified for him the two paths: the path of Light and the path of shadow, <<إِمَّا شَاكِرًا وَإِمَّا كَفُورًا>> (Either grateful or ungrateful). For the impossible non-existence is darkness (ظلمة), while the non-existence of the possible thing is a shadow (ظل), not darkness. For this reason, in the shadow there is the repose of Existence.

Know that the First Theophany (التجلي الأول) that occurred to the possible thing when it was characterized by Existence and dyed with the Light is the Theophany for the luminous spirits (الأرواح النورية) that do not possess these dark physical structures, but they do possess the shadow of their possibility (ظل إمكانها) which never leaves them. Although they are Light due to what they were dyed with, their shadow is within them, having no outward manifestation over them, yet its ruling within them does not cease. This is the degree that the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, desired to attain when he used to say in his supplication: "O God, make me Light."

After this Creative Theophany (التجلي الإبداعي), which caused some of the luminous spirits to be bewildered, He disclosed Himself in a Theophany to some of these created spirits. From this Theophany, they knew all the degrees (المراتب) that manifest from Him in the world of Lights and darknesses, subtleties and densities, simples and compounds, substances and accidents, times and places, relations, qualities, quantities, positions, agents, and patients, until the Day of Resurrection, and the types of the cosmos. Their total number is two hundred and seven thousand and six hundred degrees. This number is derived from multiplying three hundred and sixty by itself, and then adding seventy-eight thousand, resulting in the total we mentioned. This is the Knowledge of the First Intellect (العقل الأول). The age of the cosmos, from the moment this creatively effected thing (المفعول الإبداعي) took charge of observing it, is known; what preceded that is unknown, known only to God, the Exalted.

When the Intellect knew these degrees from this Theophany—and these are its sciences—among them was the emanation of the Universal Soul (النفس الكلية) from it. This is the first emanated effect (مفعول انبعاثي). It is mixed between that from which it was acted upon and that which it acted upon. That from which it was acted upon is Light, and that which it acted upon is darkness, which is Nature (الطبيعة). Thus, the shadow of the Soul appeared on its exterior, facing the side of Nature, but its shadow did not extend from it as it extends from dense bodies. All the sciences of the Intellect that we mentioned were inscribed within it. It possesses a specific face toward God that the Intellect has no knowledge of, for it is the secret of God (سر الله) between Him and every creature. Its relation is unknown, it cannot be expressed in words, and no creature can deny its existence. It is the Known Unknown. This is the Theophany *in* things (التجلي في الأشياء) that preserves their entities. As for the Theophany *to* things (التجلي للأشياء), it is a Theophany that annihilates states and grants states to the recipient of the Theophany. From this Theophany, accidents (الأعراض) and states (الأحوال) come into existence in everything other than God.

Then He has a Theophany in the totality of the Names. In this Theophany, He grants the cosmos measures, weights, places, times, Divine Laws (الشرائع), and what is appropriate for the world of bodies, the world of spirits, verbal and numerical letters, and the world of Imagination (عالم الخيال). Then He has another Theophany specifically in the Names of Relation (أسماء الإضافة), such as *Al-Khāliq* (The Creator) and similar Names. In this, generation, procreation, passive effects, transformations, and lineages appear in the cosmos. All of these are veils (حجب) over the entities of the essences (أعيان الذوات) that bear these veils, preventing them from perceiving that Theophany which belongs to these veils and which brings their entities into existence within the entities of the essences. To this extent, acts are attributed to causes. Were it not for these veils, Unveiling (الكشف) would occur, and ignorance would cease. But as He said: <<مَا يُبَدَّلُ الْقَوْلُ لَدَيَّ>> (The word is not changed with Me), and the occurrence of anything contrary to what is known is impossible. Through Theophany, the state of the Fixed Entities (الأعيان الثابتة) changes from immutability (الثبوت) to Existence (الوجود). Through it, the transition from one state to another appears in existent things, which is humility beneath the sovereignty of the Theophany. Thus, He possesses the two opposites: He erases and establishes, brings into existence and annihilates. God clarified this for us with His saying, the Exalted: <<فَلَمَّا تَجَلَّى رَبُّهُ لِلْجَبَلِ جَعَلَهُ دَكًّا>> (But when his Lord manifested His glory to the mountain, He made it crumble to dust) [Q. 7:143]. He transferred it from the state of loftiness to the state of humility and crumbling. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said in the Hadith verified by Unveiling: "When God manifests His glory to a thing, it humbles itself before Him."

God is perpetually manifesting His glory (متجل على الدوام) because changes are perpetually witnessed in the manifest and the hidden, the unseen and the witnessed, the sensible and the intelligible. His concern is Theophany, and the concern of existent things is change through transition from one state to another. Among us are those who know Him, and among us are those who do not. Whoever knows Him worships Him in every state, and whoever does not know Him denies Him in every state. It is established in the *Ṣaḥīḥ* that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Praise be to God in every state." Thus, he praised Him in every state because He is the Giver of every state through His Theophany. What is clearer than this in transmission is that which occurs alongside the establishment of limits and the rejection of what ought to be rejected. For the one who rejects by changing [the state] rejects that <<يَسْأَلُهُ مَنْ فِي السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ كُلَّ يَوْمٍ هُوَ فِي شَأْنٍ>> (Whoever is in the heavens and earth asks Him; every day He is in a [new] affair). These are Divine states in existential entities (أعيان كيانية) determined by relative Names (أسماء نسبية) which are specified by cosmic changes. He manifested Himself as a unitive Entity (أحدي العين) in entities of diverse existence, and they saw their forms within Him. Thus, the cosmos witnessed itself in that Entity. Some of it was suitable (المناسب), which is the agreeable, and some was unsuitable (غير المناسب), which is the disagreeable—this is expressed as benefit and harm. Agreement and disagreement appeared in the entities of the cosmos, both in this world and the Hereafter, because the entities of the cosmos perpetually observe one another in that manifesting Entity. Their lights are reflected upon them based on what they acquire from that Entity, and thus what occurs in the cosmos, both in this world and the Hereafter, arises from the effect of the reality of that Entity when the gazes of the cosmos attach to it. This is like a mirror facing the sun, whose light is reflected onto cotton placed opposite the reflection of the light, causing it to burn. This is precisely what appears in the cosmos regarding the influence of one part upon another through the witnessing of that Entity. The influencer is spiritual (روحاني), and the influenced is natural (طبيعي). There is nothing in the cosmos that possesses a natural form except that it has a holy spirit (روح قدسي). That Entity is never veiled. The cosmos is perpetually in a state of witnessing, and change is perpetually occurring, but [it is either] agreeable or disagreeable, which is expressed as benefit and harm. This Knowledge of Theophany is one of the divisions of Gnosis (المعرفة). If a person does not attain it, along with the rest of his brethren, he is not a Gnostic (عارف) and has not attained the station of Gnosis.

The Third Type of Gnosis (المعرفة), which is the Knowledge of the address of The Real to His servants through the tongues of the Divine Laws (الشرائع).

Know, may Allah grant you success, that everything other than the two weighty ones (Jinn and Humans) of all that is other than Allah possesses gnosis (معرفة) of Allah, revelation from Allah, and knowledge of the One who manifests Himself to it. It is inherently disposed to this, and all of it is felicitous. For this reason, the Exalted said: <<أَ لَمْ تَرَ أَنَّ الله يَسْجُدُ لَهُ من في السَّماواتِ ومن في الْأَرْضِ>> (Do you not see that Allah—to Him prostrates whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth), encompassing all, and then He specified, in order to clarify for people what was sent down to them, saying: <<والشَّمْسُ والْقَمَرُ والنُّجُومُ والْجِبالُ والشَّجَرُ والدَّوَابُّ وكَثِيرٌ من النَّاسِ>> (And the sun, and the moon, and the stars, and the mountains, and the trees, and the beasts, and many among mankind). This is followed by His saying: <<إِلَّا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا وعَمِلُوا الصَّالِحاتِ وقَلِيلٌ ما هُمْ>> (Except those who believe and do righteous deeds, and few are they). He means, "They are not few," meaning they are numerous. This corresponds to His saying: <<وكَثِيرٌ من النَّاسِ>> (And many among mankind). Then He said: <<وكَثِيرٌ حَقَّ عَلَيْهِ الْعَذابُ>> (And many upon whom the punishment is due).

The reason for this is that He entrusted the human being, by virtue of his rational soul (نفسه الناطقة) existing between Nature and Light, with the thought (الفكر) that Allah placed within it, so that he might acquire gnosis (المعرفة) of Allah the Exalted by Divine choice (اختيارا). He granted it the intellect (العقل), just as He granted it to the rest of the existents, and He gave it the quality of acceptance and its passionate love for the thinking faculty (القوة المفكرة) to deduce sciences from its own essence (ذاته), so that a Divine power might manifest within it. For the human loves leadership, manifestation, and superiority over his peers, due to their shared nature in this regard.

Then, when He granted them the thinking faculty, He established for them signs and proofs (دلائل) indicating contingency (الحدوث), due to their subsistence through their essences (أعيانهم). And He established for them proofs and signs indicating Eternity (القدم), which is the expression for negating priority from His Existence. Those very signs that He established to indicate contingency are the ones that, when negated from the Ancient Essence (الذات القديمة) named Allah, serve as the proof—nothing else. Thus, the proofs have two faces, yet they are a single entity: their affirmation indicates the contingency of the world (العالم), and their negation indicates the World’s Originator (موجد العالم).

When the human looked with this perspective and said, "I have known Allah by the proofs He established for our gnosis of ourselves and of Him," these are the signs established in the horizons and within ourselves, <<حتى يتبين لنا أنه الحق>> (until it becomes clear to us that He is The Real). And it has become clear. This is what we expressed as the Theophany (التجلي), for the Theophany is essentially the subject of vision. This is His saying: <<سَنُرِيهِمْ آياتِنا>> (We shall show them Our signs). He mentioned vision and signs for the Theophany, so that it may become clear to them that He is The Real. That is, that Theophany which they saw is a sign that it is a sign of Himself, so <<يَتَبَيَّنَ لَهُمْ أَنَّهُ الْحَقُّ>> (it becomes clear to them that He is The Real) sought. For this reason, He completed the verse itself by saying: <<أَ ولَمْ يَكْفِ بِرَبِّكَ>> (Is your Lord not sufficient?), meaning, to be a proof of Himself. The clearest of proofs is the indication of a thing upon itself through its manifestation.

When their intellects attained this gnosis (معرفة) through transcendence (التنزيه) from what they attributed to the essences of the world—and this is a single proof, oscillating in its indication between negation for the gnosis of Allah and affirmation for the gnosis of the world—The Real established for this human species a person whom He mentioned came to them from Allah with a message to inform them. They looked with the thinking faculty and saw that the matter was permissible and possible. They neither rushed to deny him nor saw a sign indicating his truthfulness. So they paused and asked him, "Have you come to us with a sign from Him, so that we may know that you are truthful in your message? For there is no difference between us and you, and we have seen nothing distinguishing you from us. The door of claim is open, and some claims are true, and some are not."

So he came with the miracle (المعجزة). They examined it with an impartial view. The miracle is between two possibilities: one, that it is within their capacity, but he claims the absolute diversion (الصرف) of that capacity, so it does not appear except through the hands of the Messenger until the Day of Resurrection—this is if it is a miracle and not merely a sign. For miracles are established for the most stubborn opponent who lacks the light of faith (نور الايمان). The other possibility is that the miracle is beyond human capacity, both physically and spiritually (بالحس والهمة معا). If he brought one of these two things, and the observer verified it as a proof, he believed in his message and affirmed his statement and his report about his Lord, provided that the indication was upon the totality according to the claim made.

However, in the taste of our path, affirmation (تصديق) along with the proof is not possible except through a Divine Theophany (تجلي إلهي) to his heart from the Name The Light (النور). If his inner being is colored by that Light, he affirms him. That is the light of faith. Others did not receive any of that Light, despite their knowledge that he was truthful based on the proof, not based on the Light cast into the heart. Thus, they denied while knowing, which is the meaning of the Exalted’s saying: <<وجَحَدُوا بِها واسْتَيْقَنَتْها أَنْفُسُهُمْ ظُلْماً وعُلُوًّا>> (And they rejected them, while their souls were convinced of them, out of injustice and arrogance). Below them in this rank are those concerning whom it was said: <<وأضله الله على علم>> (And Allah led him astray despite his knowledge). That is the light of knowledge of Him, not the light of faith.

When those who affirmed him did so, and their affirmation became manifest, they relied on their intellects, which led them to The Real, but they did not receive any illumination from the light of faith to guide them. They did not realize that they affirmed him by that Light, not by the light of their knowledge, which is also possessed by those who denied him despite knowing the truth of his claim.

When this affirming group relied on their intellects, and another group of affirmers came, Allah unveiled to them the light of their faith and the light of their knowledge, so it was "Light upon Light."

A third group came who had no light of theoretical knowledge (العلم النظري) whatsoever, nor did they know the point of indication in that miraculous sign. Allah cast the light of faith into their hearts, so they believed and affirmed. They had no light of theoretical knowledge, but they possessed a sound nature (فطرة سليمة), a receptive intellect, and an illuminated structure (هيكل منور) far removed from the use of thought. They hastened to accept.

These three types of people sat before the Messenger whom they affirmed. The Messenger began to describe his Sender, The Real, the Exalted, to make them know Him with a gnosis they did not possess, since they had deemed such attributes impossible for The Real, the Exalted, and the people of theoretical proofs (الأدلة النظرية) had negated them from Him, affirming those attributes only for contingent entities (المحدثات) as an indication of their contingency.

When they heard what the theoretical rational proofs denied and rejected, they split into factions.

One faction apostatized (ارتد على عقبه) and doubted the proof that had indicated his truthfulness. They raised doubts against that proof, which diverted them from faith and gnosis of Him, so they turned back.

Another faction said: "Among our gathering is one who possesses nothing but the light of faith and does not know what knowledge is or its path. We do not doubt the truthfulness of this Messenger or his wisdom. And part of wisdom is considering the weakest." They concluded that the Messenger addressed this weak person, who had no theoretical insight into proofs and possessed only the light of faith, with these attributes that he ascribed to his Lord, out of mercy for him, because his faith would not grow except with such a description. And The Real has the right to describe Himself as He wills, according to the capacity of the recipient's intellect, even if the reality is otherwise. This faction, who reported this description and considered the right of the weakest, relied on their own gnosis of Him, their verification of our truthfulness in it, and their adherence to their proof. None of this description compromises what they hold, since they understood the Messenger's intention by the command. Thus, they remained firm in their faith, even though they deemed impossible what the Messenger described his Lord with in their own minds, accepting it as wisdom and a means of attracting the weakest.

Another faction of those present said: "This description contradicts the proofs, yet we are certain of the truthfulness of this reporter. The limit of our gnosis of Allah is the negation of what we attribute to contingent entities. This Messenger knows more about Allah than we do regarding this attribution. So we believe in it, affirming him, and we entrust the knowledge of it to him and to Allah. For believing in this wording does not harm us, and the attribution of this description to the Exalted is unknown to us, because His Essence (ذاته) is unknown, whether through affirmative or negative attributes. Therefore, reliance is not placed on it, and ignorance of Allah is the foundation. Ignorance regarding the attribution of what The Real described Himself with in His Book is greater. So let us submit and believe based on His knowledge of what He said about Himself."

Another faction of those present said: "We do not doubt our proof regarding the truthfulness of this reporter. He has brought us matters concerning the description of Allah who sent him that, if we stopped at their apparent meaning and applied them to the Exalted as we apply them to ourselves, would lead to His contingency and negate His being God, which is established. So we must look to see if there is a linguistic interpretation (مصرف في اللسان) in the language he brought, for the Messenger was sent <<إِلَّا بِلِسانِ قَوْمِهِ>> (only with the language of his people)." They examined the avenues of interpretation for that description, seeking what implies transcendence (التنزيه) and negates anthropomorphism (التشبيه). They applied those words to that interpretation. When asked why they did this, they said: "One reason is the command not to impugn the proofs, for we established the truth of his claim by rational proofs, and we do not accept anything that impugns the rational proof, as that would impugn the proof of his truthfulness. The other reason is that this truthful one told us that Allah who sent him <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him), which agrees with the rational proofs. Thus, his truthfulness is strengthened for us by this. If we were to say what he said about Allah in the manner dictated by the apparent meaning of the word, and apply it to Him as we apply it to contingent entities, we would go astray. So we resorted to interpretation (التأويل) to affirm both paths."

Another faction, the weakest of all, did not transcend the Presence of Imagination (حضرة الخيال). They had no knowledge of the abstraction of meanings (تجريد المعاني) or of subtle secrets, nor did they understand the meaning of His saying <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him) or His saying <<وما قَدَرُوا الله حَقَّ قَدْرِهِ>> (And they did not estimate Allah with the estimation due to Him). They remain fixed in all their affairs with Imagination, yet they have the light of faith and affirmation in their hearts. They are ignorant of the language, so they took the matter according to its apparent meaning and did not entrust the knowledge of it to Allah. They believed in attributing that description to Allah just as they attribute it to themselves. There is no group weaker than this one, for they possess half of faith, having accepted the description of anthropomorphism (التشبيه) but failing to comprehend the descriptions of transcendence (التنزيه) from <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>>.

The saved faction (الفرقة الناجية) among these groups, the one that attained The Real, is the one that believed in what came from Allah according to Allah's intent and knowledge concerning it, while negating anthropomorphism by affirming <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>>.

These, O my friend, are the languages of the Divine Laws (ألسنة الشرائع) in the world. The Law brought the form (الصورة) concerning The Real: the Eye, the Hand, the Foot, Hearing, Sight, Pleasure, Wrath, Hesitation, Joy, Wonder, Laughter, Weariness, Cunning, Deceit, Mockery, Scorn, Striving, Hurrying, Descent, Establishment (الاستواء), Limitation in proximity, and Patience in the face of harm, and all that follows this course, which are attributes of creatures. This is so that we may believe generally and know that the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) in the essences of contingent entities (أعيان الممكنات) grants these attributes. Thus, there is no witness and nothing witnessed except Allah. The languages of the Laws are the proofs of the Theophanies, and the Theophanies are the proofs of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية). Thus, the doors of gnosis are linked one to another. Every word brought by the Law is according to what it brought, but our Gnostic (عالمنا) knows by which language the Law spoke, to whom it addressed, by whom it addressed, with what it addressed, to whom the acts (الأفعال) return, to whom the sayings (الأقوال) are attributed, and who is the transformer of states, and who said: <<سَنَفْرُغُ لَكُمْ أَيُّهَ الثَّقَلانِ فَبِأَيِّ آلاءِ رَبِّكُما تُكَذِّبانِ>> (We shall attend to you, O you two weighty ones! Then which of your Lord’s favors will you deny?). We respond: "Nor by anything of Your favors, our Lord, do we deny." He desired to hear this from us, and we have said it, and praise be to Allah.

***

### (The Fourth Type) of the Sciences of Gnosis: Knowledge of Perfection and Imperfection in Existence

Know that the existence of imperfection (النقص) within Existence (الوجود) is part of the perfection of Existence. For if imperfection did not exist, the perfection of Existence would be imperfect due to the absence of imperfection within it. The Exalted said concerning the perfection of everything other than Allah: <<أَعْطى‏ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ خَلْقَهُ>> (He gave everything its creation/form). Thus, He did not diminish anything at all; even imperfection was given its form. This is the perfection of the World (العالم), which is everything other than Allah, except for the human being. For Allah, there is a perfection befitting Him, and for the human, there is a perfection he accepts. Whoever among mankind falls short of this perfection, that is the imperfection found in the World, because the human is part of the World. Not every human accepts perfection, but everything else is perfect in its level (مرتبته), lacking nothing, according to the text of the Quran.

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning the human: "Many men attained perfection, and among women, Mary and Asiya." And he said, "The superiority of Aisha over other women is like the superiority of *tharid* (a dish) over other food."

Thus, imperfection did not appear in the World except in this human being. This is because he is the totality of the realities of the World (مجموع حقائق العالم); he is the concise summary (المختصر الوجيز), while the World is the detailed expanse (المطول البسيط).

As for the perfection of Divinity (كمال الألوهية), it is manifest through the Divine Laws (الشرائع), but not through the proofs of the intellects. Indeed, what the intellect sees as perfection is imperfection in the sight of Allah, if it were as the rational proof dictates. The intellect brought half of the gnosis of Allah, which is transcendence (التنزيه) and the negation of many judgments concerning the Exalted. The Lawgiver (الشارع) came, reporting from Allah the affirmation of what the intellect negated by its indication, and confirming what the intellect negated from Him. Thus, He brought both aspects for the perfection that befits the Exalted, thereby confusing the intellects (حير العقول). This is the Divine Perfection.

If He had not caused confusion regarding what He mentioned, He would have been subject to the rule of what He created. For the sensory and imaginative faculties seek Him by their essences to see their Originator, and the intellects seek Him by their essences and their proofs—through negation and affirmation, necessity, possibility, and impossibility—to know their Originator. So He addressed the senses and the Imagination with His abstraction (تجريده), which the proofs of the intellects indicated, and the senses heard, so the senses and the Imagination were confused and said, "We have nothing of Him in our hands." And He addressed the intellects with His anthropomorphism (تشبيهه), which the senses and the Imagination indicated, and the intellects heard, so the intellects were confused and said, "We have nothing of Him in our hands." Thus, He rose above the comprehension of the intellects, senses, and Imagination, and He alone, the Glorified, was unique in the confusion (الحيرة) inherent in Perfection. None knows Him but Him, and none witnesses Him but Him. They did not encompass Him with knowledge, nor did they see His Essence.

Thus, there are traces that bear witness, a presence that is sought, a rank that is praised, a God who is transcendent (منزه), and an anthropomorphic one (مشبه) who is worshipped. This is the Divine Perfection.

The human remains in an intermediate state between the perfection of confusion and limitation (الحد), which is the perfection of the World. Through the human, the World was perfected, but the human was not perfected by the World. Since the realities of the World are contained within the human, by virtue of his humanity, he is distinguished from the World only by his small size. His rank of perfection remains for him. All existents accepted their perfection, and The Real is perfect. The human is divided into two parts: a part that did not accept perfection, which is part of the World, though it is the comprehensive summary of the greater whole; and a part that accepted perfection, in which the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) manifested with its perfection and all its Names, due to his preparedness. This latter part He established as a Caliph (خليفة) and clothed him in the garment of confusion concerning Him.

The Angels looked at the constitution of his body (نشأة جسده) and said what they said about it, due to the disparity of the realities that Allah compounded within his body. When The Real informed them of what He created him upon and what He granted him, they were confused concerning him and said, "We have no knowledge." And the confused one has no knowledge.
