Then He granted him the knowledge of the Divine Names (علم الأسماء الإلهية) with which the Angels had not glorified Him or sanctified Him, as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "He will praise Allah tomorrow on the Day of Resurrection, when asked for intercession, with praises that he does not know now, which the station requires."

For the praises of Allah the Exalted are according to what the stations and constitutions require. The constitution of Adam and those of his descendants who resemble him granted the eligibility for the Caliphate (الخلافة) in the World, and this was not granted to others. Thus, the perfection of the human was achieved through this preparedness for this specific Theophany (التجلي الخاص). He manifested by the Names of The Real in their opposition, and The Real granted him the means of their application in what He clarified for him. Thus, he manifests by what his vicegerency manifests, which is called The Real and Justice (الحق والعدل) in the Caliphate. Allah said to David: <<إِنَّا جَعَلْناكَ خَلِيفَةً في الْأَرْضِ فَاحْكُمْ بَيْنَ النَّاسِ بِالْحَقِّ ولا تَتَّبِعِ الْهَوى‏>> (Indeed, We have made you a vicegerent [khalīfah] on the earth, so judge between the people with the truth and do not follow caprice), lest caprice cause the follower to fall from this rank for which he was made eligible, and for which you and your likes were made eligible, as Abu al-Atahiyya said:

> The Caliphate came to him submissively,
> Dragging its trains behind it.
> It was not fit for anyone but him,
> And he was not fit for anyone but it.
> Had anyone else sought it,
> The earth would have been shaken by its tremor.

If he is granted authority (التحكم) in the World, that is the Caliphate. If he wills, he rules and purifies, like Abd al-Qadir al-Jilani. If he wills, he submits and leaves the disposal of affairs to his Lord concerning His servants, while possessing the capacity to rule—which is necessary—like Abu Mas'ud ibn al-Shibli. However, if a Divine command (أمر إلهي) is coupled with it, as with David, peace be upon him, there is no way to reject Allah's command, for that rejection is the caprice (الهوى) that was forbidden to follow. And like Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, who did not remove the garment of the Caliphate from his neck until he was killed, due to his knowledge of what The Real had decreed for him, for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade him from removing the garment of the Caliphate.

Thus, whoever’s rule is coupled with a Divine command must manifest it and will remain supported. Whoever’s rule is not coupled with a Divine command is given a choice: if he wills to manifest it, he manifests it rightfully; if he wills not to manifest it, he conceals himself rightfully. Concealment is preferable. Thus, the saints (الأولياء) join the Prophets only in the Caliphate, but they do not join them in Messengership (الرسالة) or Prophethood (النبوة), for those doors are closed. The Messenger has the judgment (الحكم). If he is made a Caliph, he has the authority. If he is a Messenger, his authority is by what he legislated. If he is not a Messenger, his authority is by Allah's command, according to the ruling of his time, which is the law of his era. For it is by judgment that he is attributed with justice or injustice.

*End of the One Hundred and Tenth Part.*

***

### (In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

### (The Fifth Type) of the Sciences of Gnosis: Knowledge of Man by His Realities

Know that man was not granted authority (التحكم) in the World by virtue of his humanity. Rather, he was granted it by a Divine, Lordly power (قوة إلهية ربانية), for nothing rules the World except an attribute of The Real (صفة حق), and nothing else. This power in man is a trial (ابتلاء), not an honor (تشريف). If it were an honor, it would remain with him in the Hereafter in the abode of the felicitous. If it were an honor, he would not have been told: <<ولا تَتَّبِعِ الْهَوى‏>> (And do not follow caprice), for he was restricted, and restriction is a trial, while honor is freedom.

Nor is the authority attributed to justice or injustice. Only the People of Allah (أهل الله) are entrusted with the Caliphate in the World. Rather, Allah entrusts authority in the World to whomever He makes felicitous and whomever He makes wretched among the believers. Despite this, The Real commanded us to listen to him and obey him, and not to withdraw a hand from obedience, saying: "If they are unjust, it is for you and against them." This is a state of trial, not a state of honor, for in his movements within it, he is on guard and on the edge of delusion. For this reason, some Caliphs will feel regret on the Day of Resurrection.

When man stands upon the gnosis of himself and occupies himself with the knowledge of his realities (حقائقه) from the perspective of his humanity, he sees no difference between himself and the World. He sees that the World—which is everything other than the two weighty ones—prostrates to Allah; it is obedient, fulfilling the worship of its Creator and Originator incumbent upon it. He seeks the reality in which he unites with the World, and he finds nothing but possibility (الإمكان), need (الافتقار), lowliness (الذلة), submission (الخضوع), want, and destitution.

Then he looks at how The Real described the entire World, and he sees that He described it as prostrating to Him, even its shadow. He sees that only the many (الكثير) of his own species were described thus, not the whole, unlike every other species of the World. So he fears being among the many upon whom the punishment is due.

Then he sees that the World was inherently disposed (فطروا بالذات) to the worship of Allah, and this human being is in need of someone to guide him and show him the path leading to his felicity with Allah, having heard Allah say: <<وما خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ والْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me). So he worships Him through his need for Him, just as the rest of the World worships Him.

Then he sees that Allah has set limits for him and prescribed matters, and forbade him from transgressing them, and commanded him to perform as much of His command as he is able. Thus, it became incumbent upon him to know what Allah legislated for him, so that he might establish the secondary worship (العبادة الفرعية) just as he established the original worship (العبادة الأصلية). For original worship is that which the essences of contingent entities demand by virtue of their contingency, while secondary worship consists of acts in which the servant needs Divine information regarding what his Master deserves and what his servitude requires.

If he knows his Master's command and prohibition, and fulfills the right of his Exalted Master and the right of his servitude, he has known himself. And whoever knows himself knows his Lord. And whoever knows his Lord worships Him by His command.

Only the two weighty ones combine the two forms of worship: the worship of command and the worship of prohibition. For the angelic spirits have no prohibition. He said concerning them: <<لا يَعْصُونَ الله ما أَمَرَهُمْ>> (They do not disobey Allah in what He commands them), and He did not mention prohibition for them. And concerning their essential worship (عبادتهم الذاتية), He said: <<يُسَبِّحُونَ لَهُ بِاللَّيْلِ والنَّهارِ وهُمْ لا يَسْأَمُونَ>> (They glorify Him by night and day, and they do not tire), and <<يُسَبِّحُونَ اللَّيْلَ والنَّهارَ لا يَفْتُرُونَ>> (They glorify night and day, and they do not cease). For the reality of their constitution dictates that. This is the essential worship, and it is a worship that flows through everything other than Allah.

Since man is the totality of the realities of the World, as we said, and he knows himself from the perspective of his realities, it becomes incumbent upon him to perform, by himself, the worship of the entire World. If he does not do so, he has not known himself from the perspective of his realities, because it is an essential worship.

The form of his gnosis of this is that he witnesses all his realities in their worship through Unveiling (كشفا), exactly as they are in themselves, whether he is unveiled to this or not. If he witnesses them, it becomes impossible for him to violate his Master's command regarding the worship He commanded, by adhering to His limits and ordinances in what he enters into and what he leaves.

If he says "Glory be to Allah" with his whole being, according to what we have prescribed, all that the entire World has said is inscribed in the essence of his soul through that glorification. This is the pure soul (النفس الزكية) that is called the Tongue of the World (لسان العالم). If it were possible for anything in the World to cease its worship of its Lord, this Gnostic servant, knowing this capacity, would stand in its place regarding what it neglected and fill its void—if this were conceivable.

This servant is rewarded by The Real with this capacity, which is the reward of the lesser (الأصغر) receiving the prize of the greater (الأكبر). He says: "If we supposed that the entire World, excluding the human, neglected the remembrance of Allah for the blink of an eye, and this human was remembering Allah and fulfilling His right in that moment, he would stand in the place of the World and fill its void." Thus, he would be rewarded with the reward of the entire World, even though negligence is inconceivable from the World, for only the two weighty ones are capable of negligence. Look at what the knowledge of yourself and the realities of the cosmos you embody grants you.

***

### (The Sixth Type) of the Sciences of Gnosis: Knowledge of Imagination (علم الخيال)

And its connected and separated worlds. This is a great pillar of gnosis. This is the science of the Isthmus (علم البرزخ), the science of the bodies in which spiritual entities (الروحانيات) appear, the science of the market of Paradise (سوق الجنة), the science of the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) on the Day of Resurrection in forms of transformation, the science of the manifestation of meanings that cannot subsist by themselves in embodied form, such as Death in the form of a ram. It is the science of what people see in sleep, and the science of the station where creation resides after death and before resurrection. It is the science of forms, and in it, visible forms appear in polished bodies like mirrors.

After the knowledge of the Divine Names and the universality of Theophany, there is no pillar more complete than this, for it is the central jewel of the necklace. To it the senses ascend, and to it the meanings descend. It never leaves its station. <<تُجْبى إِلَيْهِ ثَمَراتُ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ>> (The fruits of everything are gathered to it). It is the master of the elixir (صاحب الإكسير) that you apply to a meaning, and it embodies it in whatever form it wills. Its penetration in disposal and judgment is never halted. The Divine Laws support it, and natures confirm it. It is the one witnessed to possess complete disposal. It is responsible for the fusion of meanings with bodies. It confuses proofs and intellects. We shall explain it, God willing, in this chapter in the most concise and eloquent way possible. Allah is the Granter of success; there is no Lord but Him.

Know, O our brothers, that there is no known thing (معلوم), whatever it may be, that does not have a relation to Existence (الوجود) in some way, for Existence is of four types:

1.  **Actual Existence (الوجود العيني):** That which exists in itself, whatever its reality, whether characterized by being contained (الدخول) and external (الخروج) or by the negation of both. Thus, while existing in its essence, it is neither inside the World nor outside it, due to the absence of the condition for being inside or outside, which is spatial limitation (التحيز). This applies only to Allah exclusively. As for what belongs to the World, subsisting by itself but not spatially limited—such as the rational souls, the First Intellect, the Soul, the bewildered spirits (الأرواح المهيمة), Nature, and the Dust (الهباء)—all of this is contained within the World, yet it is neither inside the bodies of the World nor outside them, for they are not spatially limited.
2.  **Mental Existence (الوجود الذهني):** This is the known thing being conceived in the soul exactly as it is in its reality. If the conception does not correspond to the reality, then it does not possess mental existence.
3.  **Verbal Existence (الوجود اللفظي):** Known things have existence in words. This includes every known thing, even the impossible (المحال) and non-existence (العدم), for they have verbal existence. The impossible exists in speech but can never accept actual existence. As for non-existence, if it is the non-existence attributed to the possible (الممكن), it accepts actual existence. If it is the non-existence that is the impossible, it does not accept actual existence.
4.  **Written Existence (الوجود الكتابي):** This is numerical existence (الوجود الرقمي), which is its relation to existence in script, number, or writing. The relation of all known things, whether impossible or otherwise, is a single relation. Thus, even if the impossible has no actual essence, it has a relation of existence in speech and script. Therefore, there is no known thing that is not characterized by some aspect of existence. The reason for this is the power of Existence, which is the Origin of Origins (أصل الأصول), which is Allah the Exalted. Through Him, these levels (المراتب) appeared, and these realities were determined. By His Existence, those who accept all levels of existence are distinguished from those who do not. The Names, whether spoken or written, extend their existence over every known thing, so that known thing is characterized by a mode of existence. Thus, there is nothing in knowledge that is absolutely non-existent, having no relation to Existence whatsoever. This is inconceivable. Understand this foundation and verify it.

Then know after this that the reality of Absolute Imagination (الخيال المطلق) is what is called *al-'Ama'* (The Cloud/Primordial Mist), which is the first container (ظرف) that accepted the Being (كينونة) of The Real.

It is reported in the *Sahih* collection that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked: "Where was our Lord before He created His creation?" He said: "He was in a Cloud (*'Ama'*)—there was no air above it and no air below it."

He said this because *al-'Ama'* among the Arabs is the thin cloud that has air below it and air above it. When He named it *al-'Ama'*, He removed what the Arabs might initially understand from that, negating the air from it so that it might be known that it does not resemble it in any way. It is the first thing described by the Being of The Real within it. For The Real has five Beings, as He informed: a Being in *al-'Ama'*, which is what we mentioned; a Being on the Throne, which is His saying: <<الرَّحْمنُ عَلَى الْعَرْشِ اسْتَوى‏>> (The Most Compassionate established Himself upon the Throne); a Being in the heaven, in His saying: "Our Lord descends every night to the lowest heaven"; a Being on the earth, which is His saying: <<وهُوَ الله في السَّماواتِ وفي الْأَرْضِ>> (And He is Allah in the heavens and on the earth); and a general Being, which is His being with the existents according to their levels, wherever they may be, as He clarified concerning us when He said: <<وهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are). All these relations are according to what befits His Majesty, without modality (تكييف), anthropomorphism (تشبيه), or conception, but rather as His Essence dictates and what is proper to be attributed to it: <<لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْعَزِيزُ>> (There is no god but He, the Almighty). No one can attain gnosis or success in grasping His reality, <<الْحَكِيمُ>> (the Wise), who descended to His servants in His words, bringing the distant near in address for a wisdom He intended, the Exalted.

Allah the Exalted opened up in that *'Ama'* the forms of everything other than Him in the World. That *'Ama'* is the verified Imagination (الخيال المحقق). Do you not see that it accepts the forms of all contingent entities and forms what is not contingent? This is due to its vastness. It is the very essence of *al-'Ama'*, nothing else. In it appeared all existents. It is what is expressed as the Manifest (الظاهر) aspect of The Real in His saying: <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ والْآخِرُ والظَّاهِرُ والْباطِنُ>> (He is the First and the Last, the Manifest and the Inner). For this reason, in the Connected Imagination (الخيال المتصل), one who lacks gnosis of what befits Allah's Majesty imagines Him in a form. If the Connected Imagination rules over him, what do you think of the Absolute Imagination (الخيال المطلق), which is the Being of The Real within it, and which is *al-'Ama'*?

From that power, the Connected Imagination controls it. Then the Law came in places confirming what the Connected Imagination controlled regarding the Being of The Real in the direction of the worshipper (قبلة المصلي) and in the worshipper's facing Him. The Connected Imagination accepted it, and it is one of the aspects of the Absolute Imagination, which is the comprehensive Presence (الحضرة الجامعة) and the all-encompassing level.

The emergence of this *'Ama'* is from the Breath of the Merciful (نفس الرحمن), from His being God (إلها), not merely from His being the Merciful (رحمانا). All existents appeared in *al-'Ama'* by the command "Be" (كن) or by the Divine Hand or Hands, except for *al-'Ama'*, whose appearance is specifically by the Breath (النفس). Were it not for what is reported in the Law, we would not have used the term Breath, despite our knowledge of it. The origin of this was the rule of Love (الحب). Love involves movement in the lover, and the Breath is a movement of longing (حركة شوقية) for the one who is passionately loved and attached to. In that breathing, there is pleasure. The Exalted said, as reported: "I was a hidden treasure, and I loved to be known."

By this Love, the breathing occurred, and the Breath appeared, and *al-'Ama'* came into being. For this reason, the Lawgiver applied the name *al-'Ama'* to it, because the cloud (*'Ama'*) is generated from vapors, which are the breath of the elements, due to the effect of heat within them. Because of this analogy, He named it *'Ama'*. Then He negated the air that surrounds it, as air surrounds the body of a cloud and directs it as it wills. Thus, He negated that anything other than Him controls this *'Ama'*, since it is the closest of existents to Allah, existing from His Breath.

When this *'Ama'* filled the entire void (الخلأ)—which is the place or container of the World, for if the World ceased to exist, the void would become apparent, and it is an imagined extension in a non-body—this *'Ama'* is The Real created by which everything exists (الحق المخلوق به كل شي‏ء). It is called The Real because it is the essence of the Breath, and the Breath is hidden within the breather—this is how it is conceived. The Breath has the rule of the Inner (الباطن). When it manifests, it has the rule of the Manifest (الظاهر). Thus, He is <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ>> (the First) in the Inner and <<والْآخِرُ>> (the Last) in the Manifest, and <<وهُوَ بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ عَلِيمٌ>> (And He is Knower of all things), for everything named appeared within it, whether non-existent that can exist actually, or non-existent whose actual existence appears.

Then, within the essence of this *'Ama'* appeared the spirits of the bewildered Angels (أرواح الملائكة المهيمة)—and they are not Angels, but purified spirits. Then, the forms of the species of the World continued to appear within it, stage after stage, until it was complete in terms of its species. When it was complete, the individuals (الأشخاص) of these species continued to be formed perpetually, a formation of transformation (تكوينا استحالة) from existence to existence, not from non-existence to existence. Adam was created from dust, and the children of Adam were created from semen, which is despised water. Then He created <<النُّطْفَةَ عَلَقَةً>> (the drop of semen into a clinging clot). For this reason, we said that individuals are created from existence, not from non-existence. For the origin was based on this, and that origin is *al-'Ama'* from the Breath, and the Breath is Existence, and it is the Essence of The Real by which creation occurs. The species of the World are created from *al-'Ama'*, and the individuals of the World are also created from *al-'Ama'* and from the types of its species. Nothing was created from non-existence that cannot exist. Rather, it appeared in the Fixed Entities (أعيان ثابتة).

This is our saying at the beginning of this book: "Praise be to Allah who brought things into existence from non-existence, and their non-existence from non-existence," meaning that they did not have a manifest essence, and their non-existence and the non-existence of non-existence is Existence. That is, even if they had no essence, this essence appeared from Existence in reality, thereby annihilating the first non-existence that He affirmed by a certain relation. Thus, from that relation, it is fixed, and from this other relation, it is negated.

If you verify this, you may say, if you wish, that it is from non-existence, or you may say that it is from existence, after knowing the matter as it truly is. Were it not for the power of Imagination (الخيال), nothing of what we have manifested to you would have appeared, for it is the most expansive of contingent entities and the most perfect of existents. It accepts spiritual forms (الصور الروحانيات), which is the embodiment in different forms through transformation (الاستحالة).

Transformation is of two types: one involves speed, like the transformation of spirits into bodily forms and meanings into bodily forms that appear in the being of this *'Ama'*. The other involves slowness, like the transformation of water into air, air into fire, semen into a human, and elements into plants and animals. Although all of these are transformations, they do not possess the speed of the transformation of forms in the imaginative faculty (القوة المتخيلة) in man, which is the Connected Imagination, nor the speed of the transformation of spiritual forms into bodily forms, such as Angels in the forms of humans, for the speed there is stronger.

Likewise, their disappearance is faster than the transformations of bodies after death into what they transform into.

If you understand this foundation, you know that The Real is the Speaker, the Mover, the Stillness-Giver, the Originator, and the Annihilator. Thus, you know that all forms, with what is attributed to them, are an established Imagination (خيال منصوب) belonging to Him, and that the reality of Existence belongs to Him, the Exalted. Do you not see that the one who sets up the curtain of Imagination (خيال الستارة) only sets it up so that the observer may verify the knowledge of what the matter of Existence is? He sees multiple forms whose movements, disposals, and judgments belong to a single essence that has nothing of that itself. The Originator, Mover, and Stillness-Giver of those forms is behind that curtain (الستارة المضروبة) that separates us from Him. By it, distinction occurs, so He is called God, and we are called servants and the World—whatever term you wish.

Furthermore, this *'Ama'* is the very essence of the Isthmus (البرزخ) between meanings that have no actual essences in existence and luminous bodies and Nature, such as knowledge (العلم) and movement (الحركة)—the former in souls, the latter in bodies. They become embodied in the Presence of Imagination, like knowledge in the form of milk. Likewise, the determination of relations, even if they have no essence in the soul or the body, such as stability (الثبات) in a matter—a relation to the thing that is stable—this stability appears in the form of a tangible chain (القيد المحسوس) in the Presence of the Connected Imagination. And like spirits in the forms of embodied bodies that manifest them, such as Gabriel in the form of Dihya, and the Angels who appeared in the forms of tiny ants on the Day of Badr—this is in the Separated Imagination (الخيال المنفصل). And like the staff and ropes in the forms of snakes that crawl, as He said: <<يُخَيَّلُ إِلَيْهِ>> (It was imagined to him), meaning to Moses, <<من سِحْرِهِمْ>> (from their magic), meaning from their knowledge of what they did, <<أَنَّها تَسْعى‏>> (that they were crawling). They established that in the Presence of Imagination, and Moses perceived them as imagined, but he did not know they were imagined; rather, he thought they were like his staff in reality. For this reason, he feared, and it was said to him: <<لا تَخَفْ إِنَّكَ أَنْتَ الْأَعْلى‏>> (Do not fear; indeed, you are the superior).

The difference between the Connected Imagination and the Separated Imagination is that the Connected Imagination vanishes with the disappearance of the imaginer, while the Separated Imagination is a self-subsistent Presence (حضرة ذاتية) that is constantly receptive to meanings and spirits, embodying them by its inherent property, and it cannot be otherwise. The Connected Imagination originates from this Separated Imagination.

The Connected Imagination is of two types: one that arises from imagining, and one that does not arise from imagining, such as the sleeper, whose visions in sleep are not from imagining. The one that arises from imagining is what a person holds in his soul, such as what he perceived by the senses, or what the formative faculty (القوة المصورة) created as a form that the senses did not perceive in its totality, though all the parts of the totality must have been sensed. The imagined form of the Angel in the form of a human, which belongs to the Separated Imagination, may be included in the Connected Imagination, which then raises it. It is an imagination between them, a sensory form, without which the Connected Imagination would not have raised its likeness.

From this category is the Divine Theophany in the forms of beliefs (صور الاعتقادات), and this is something that must be believed.

Muslim reported in his *Sahih* collection, in the long Hadith of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, that: "...until none remains except those who worshipped Allah, whether righteous or wicked. Then the Lord of the Worlds, Blessed and Exalted, comes to them in the lowest form of the one they saw Him in." He says: "What are you waiting for? Let every nation follow what it used to worship." They say: "O our Lord, we separated from people in the world when we were most in need of them, and we did not accompany them." He says: "I am your Lord." They say: "We seek refuge in Allah from you. We do not associate anything with Allah," two or three times, until some of them are almost about to turn back. He says: "Is there a sign between you and your Lord by which you recognize Him?" They say: "Yes." He said: "Then <<يُكْشَفُ عَنْ ساقٍ>> (a shin is uncovered). Then no one who used to prostrate to Allah willingly remains except that he is permitted to prostrate. And no one who used to prostrate out of fear and hypocrisy remains except that Allah makes his back a single layer; whenever he tries to prostrate, he falls on his back. Then they raise their heads, and He has transformed into the form in which they saw Him the first time. He says: 'I am your Lord.' They say: 'Yes, You are our Lord.'"

Look with the eye of impartiality at this report of The Real, the Glorified, transforming into forms—and He is He, nothing else. They denied Him in one form and affirmed Him in another, yet the Essence is one and the forms are different. This is exactly what we intended regarding the difference in forms in *al-'Ama'*, meaning the forms of the World. The forms, as forms, are the imagined things, and *al-'Ama'* in which they appear is Imagination. In this Hadith is a cure for every afflicted person if he uses it with sound, impartial insight, seeking The Real.

Similarly, His Theophany upon the hearts and in the essences of contingent entities: He is the Manifest, and He is the forms, according to what the essences of contingent entities grant by their preparedness in the one in whom He appears. The contingent entities are *al-'Ama'*, and the one who appears in it is The Real, and *al-'Ama'* is The Real by which creation occurs. The difference in the essences of contingent entities lies in their inherent fixity and the judgment applied to them in the one in whom He appears.

Likewise, The Real manifests to the sleeper in his sleep, and the sleeper knows that it is The Real and does not doubt. Similarly in Unveiling (الكشف). The dream interpreter tells him, "You have truly seen," and this is in the Connected Imagination. How vast is the Presence of Imagination! In it appears the existence of the impossible (وجود المحال). Indeed, in reality, only the existence of the impossible appears in it, for the Necessary Existent, which is Allah the Exalted, does not accept forms, yet He appeared in a form in this Presence. Thus, the impossible existence accepted existence in this Presence.

In it, a body is seen in two places, just as Adam saw himself outside the grasp of The Real, but when The Real extended His Hand, Adam and his progeny were in it (the Hadith). So he is in the grasp, and he is the same one outside the grasp. This Presence accepts nothing but the existence of impossibilities.

Likewise, a person is sleeping in his house and sees himself in his familiar form in another city and in another state that contradicts his current state, and he is the same person, nothing else, for one who knows the matter of Existence as it truly is. Were it not for this scent, the rational people would not be able to hypothesize the impossible when seeking proof for a matter, because if the impossible did not accept existence in some Presence, it would not be valid to hypothesize or estimate it. When you mention this to someone who hypothesizes it, he forgets, by inherent property, the ruling of what he hypothesized and says, "The existence of the impossible is inconceivable," yet he hypothesizes its existence and judges it as he judges the actual. If he did not conceive it, he would not judge it. If he conceives it, it has accepted existence in some relation. Verify what we have said, and you will find The Real.

From this category is the witnessing of the one killed in the path of Allah in battle, while in reality he is alive, sustained, and eating. The believer perceives him by his faith, and the unveiled one (المكاشف) by his sight. And like the dead person in his grave, whom one witnesses as silent, yet he is speaking, questioning, and answering. If you say to the one who sees this that it was imagined to him, he will tell you, "Rather, it was imagined to you that he is silent while he is speaking, and imagined to you that he is lying down while he is sitting." He is supported in his statement by faith in the sound report that has come, which is stronger in indication than you. His eye is more complete in vision than yours. The one with complete vision, who is more complete than both, says to each one, "You have spoken the truth. He is silent and speaking, lying down and sitting, killed and alive." Every form witnessed in him is from the category we mentioned.

From this is the image in the mirror and every polished body. If the polished body is large, the visible image in it is large. If you look at the image from the outside, you find it is not diversified in what appeared in it of diversification due to the diversification of the viewers, even in the ripples of water, the image appears rippling. Every eye, that is, every gaze, tells the other that it is in the station of Imagination, and that The Real is with it, and every gaze is truthful. Thus, you know with certainty that the image seen in mirrors and polished bodies appears only in Imagination, like the vision of the sleeper and the embodiment of the spiritual entity (تشكل الروحاني), and that it is neither in the mirror nor in the senses, for it contradicts the sensory image in terms of its specific relation to the viewer, not the mirror. There is nothing in existence, hidden or manifest, except what we have mentioned.

Likewise, the perceptions of Paradise: its fruit is <<لا مَقْطُوعَةٍ ولا مَمْنُوعَةٍ>> (neither cut off nor forbidden), despite the existence of eating and the removal of restriction. One eats it without cutting, merely by plucking it and its proximity to the person, and its not being forbidden from plucking, and the existence of eating, while the essence remains on the branch of the tree. You witness it as uncut, and you witness it plucked in your hand, eating it, and you know and do not doubt that the very thing you eat is the very thing you witness on the branch of its tree, uncut.

Likewise, the market of Paradise (سوق الجنة) where beautiful forms appear. When the people of Paradise look at them, they enter into every form they desire, wear it, and appear in it in their kingdom. Yet, to his eye, the form in the market has not separated or been lost. If everyone in Paradise desired it, they would enter into it, and it would remain in the market as it was.

All this is analogous to realities, like whiteness in every white thing by its essence, without it being divided or fragmented. Rather, the reality of whiteness is intelligible; nothing of it is diminished, despite its existence in every white thing. Likewise, animality in every animal, and humanity in every human. All rational people acknowledge this, yet they deny what we mentioned concerning these matters in Theophany and otherwise. What came of this in the Book and the Sunnah is acknowledged by the believers, who support the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف), while the people of theoretical speculation (أصحاب النظر) deny it. If they accept it, they accept it with a far-fetched interpretation (تأويل بعيد) or by submission to the one who said it, if the speaker is Allah or His Messenger. But if something similar appears from you, they ignore you and deny it, attributing you to corruption of the Imagination (فساد الخيال).

Yet, they acknowledge what they deny, for they affirm Imagination and its corruption, and its corruption does not indicate its non-existence. Rather, its corruption is when it does not correspond, in their view, to the correct reality, which is correct. Whether you call it correct or corrupt, its essence is established, and that form is in Imagination. Let it be correct or corrupt; I do not care. Our intention was only to establish the existence of Imagination. We did not address the correctness of what appears in it or its corruption.

It is established that the judgment belongs to Imagination in every aspect and in every state: in the sensible and the intelligible, in the senses and the intellects, in forms and meanings, in the contingent and the Ancient, in the impossible, the possible, and the Necessary. Whoever does not know the level of Imagination has no gnosis whatsoever. If this pillar of gnosis is not attained by the Gnostics, they have not even a scent of gnosis.

Furthermore, what supports what we mentioned is that you do not doubt that what you perceive is a tangible reality, because the sense faculty is attached to it. The Hadith reported from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, states: "People are asleep, and when they die, they awaken."

He alerted us that what you perceive in this abode is like the perception of the sleeper; rather, it is the perception of the sleeper in sleep, and it is Imagination (خيال). You do not doubt that people in the Isthmus (البرزخ) between this abode and the Hereafter are in the station of Imagination. Your awakening by death is like someone who sees himself waking up in sleep while still asleep, and he says in his sleep, "I saw such and such," believing he has awakened. This report is supported by the Exalted’s saying concerning the dead person: <<فَكَشَفْنا عَنْكَ غِطاءَكَ فَبَصَرُكَ الْيَوْمَ حَدِيدٌ>> (We have removed your veil from you, and your sight today is sharp). That is, you perceive what you did not perceive before death, so it is an awakening relative to the state you were in during the life of this world. Then, when you are resurrected in the next constitution, the resurrected one says: <<من بَعَثَنا من مَرْقَدِنا هذا>> (Who has raised us from our sleeping place?). Thus, his state during the period of his death was like the sleeper in his sleep, even though the Lawgiver called it an awakening.

Likewise, every state you are in, you must transition out of it, and it remains like what you were upon in your Connected Imagination, and in the power of its being a reality in the Separated Imagination. For if it were a reality, it would not change or transition, since realities do not change. The reality of Imagination is transformation in every state and manifestation in every form.

There is no true Existence that does not accept change except Allah. Thus, there is nothing in verified Existence except Allah. As for everything else, it is in the Imaginative Existence (الوجود الخيالي). When The Real appears in this Imaginative Existence, He appears only according to its reality, not by His Essence (ذاته) which possesses true Existence. For this reason, the sound Hadith came with His transformation into forms in His Theophany to His servants.

This is His saying: <<كُلُّ شَيْءٍ هالِكٌ>> (Everything is perishing). No state whatsoever remains in the World—neither cosmic nor Divine—<<إِلَّا وَجْهَهُ>> (except His Face), meaning His Essence, for the face of a thing is its essence. It does not perish. Where is the form into which He transformed from the form from which He transformed? This is the share of the form from which He transformed in the attribution of perishing to it.

Everything other than the Essence of The Real is in the station of rapid and slow transformation. Everything other than the Essence of The Real is a fleeting imagination (خيال حائل) and a vanishing shadow (ظل زائل). No being in this world, the Hereafter, or what is between them, no spirit, no soul, and nothing other than Allah—meaning the Essence of The Real—remains in a single state; rather, it constantly transforms from form to form, eternally. Imagination is nothing but this. This is the very intelligibility of Imagination. Look at the foundation where He spoke of *al-'Ama'* and likened it to a cloud. Likening is imagining (تخيل), and *al-'Ama'* is the essence of the entire World. The World only appeared in Imagination, so it is imagined by itself. Thus, it is He, and it is not He.

What supports what we mentioned is: <<وما رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ>> (And you did not throw when you threw). He negated the very thing He affirmed. That is, you imagined that you threw, yet there is no doubt that he threw, which is why He said: <<إِذْ رَمَيْتَ>> (when you threw). Then He said that the throwing is correct, <<ولكِنَّ الله رَمى‏>> (but Allah threw). That is, O Muhammad, you appeared in the form of The Real, so your throw struck what the throw of a human cannot strike, just as Jesus breathed into the form of a bird, and it became a bird. The Divine Breath appeared in the breath of Jesus, which is His saying: <<ونَفَخْتُ فِيهِ من رُوحِي>> (And I breathed into him of My Spirit). The breath is the *Nafs* (Breath/Soul), and *al-'Ama'* is the essence of that Breath. Thus, it is a breathing into the Existence of The Real, from which creation was formed in The Real. Thus, The Real by which creation occurs is what appeared of the forms of the World within it, and what appeared of the difference in the Divine Theophany within it. This much is sufficient for our purpose concerning the science of Imagination.

The knowledge of the earth that was created from the remainder of Adam's clay, which is what appeared of the forms of the World within it, has already been presented in this book. The knowledge of that earth is a part of this issue.

***

### (The Seventh Type) of Gnosis: Knowledge of Causes and Remedies

It is needed by the Shaykhs (الشيوخ) who undertake spiritual training. These remedies are only beneficial for those who accept their application; if the afflicted person (العليل) does not use them, no effect will appear. Therefore, we shall explain, God willing, the ailments by enumerating their root causes, and then mention the specific remedies for them.

The ailments in this Path (الطريقة) pertain exclusively to the souls (النفوس); the intellects (العقول) and the bodies (الأبدان) have absolutely no share in them. For the ailments of the intellects are known, and the ailments of the bodies are known. The remedies for bodily ailments are entrusted to physicians, and the remedies for intellectual ailments are the adoption of retreats (الخلوات) according to the natural balance, the removal of excessive contemplation (التفكر) therein, and the constant practice of remembrance (الذكر), nothing else. What remains for us to delve into are the ailments of the souls, which are three types of diseases: a disease in speech (الأقوال), a disease in actions (الأفعال), and a disease in spiritual states (الأحوال). As for the disease of beliefs (الاعتقادات), that is a disease of the intellects, which we have already mentioned.

Let us mention the diseases of speech. One of them is the insistence on speaking the truth (قول الحق), which is one of the greatest diseases. Its remedy is the knowledge of the proper contexts (المواطن) in which it should be employed. For backbiting (الغيبة) is true, yet it is forbidden. Slander (النميمة) is true, yet it is forbidden. And what a man says about what he does with his wife in his bed when he approaches her, speaking the truth about it—this speech is among the major sins (الكبائر). And advising publicly (النصيحة في الملإ) with the truth is true, yet it is a disgrace (فضيحة) and only occurs among the ignorant (الجهلاء) and those with ulterior motives (أصحاب الأغراض). This is because the desired benefit of advice is the attainment of benefit and the establishment of affection. If the advice is given publicly, acceptance is not achieved, and it yields enmity. God condemns this, for the person is shamed by that public advice, and it causes the person addressed to lie in his excuse for it, and he harbors resentment against the advisor. This becomes a cause for great corruption. If he had advised him in private (في خلوة) in a good manner, by revealing his own fault in the matter itself without making him feel that he was the target—to inform him if he was ignorant of the ugliness of the matter he was advised about—the person would thank him inwardly, love him, pray for him, and it would yield good for him and be placed in his balance (of good deeds). Thus, not every truth is commanded, nor is it deemed good by Sacred Law (شرعا) or custom (عرفا).

Likewise, he who confronts people with what they dislike, even if it is true, demonstrates baseness of character (لؤم الطباع), ignorance, and lack of shame before God. It is unlikely that he himself is free from a fault displeasing to God. If he occupied himself with examining his own fault, that would distract him from the fault of others.

And he who commits himself to tracking the movements of his companion, to the extent of recording his very breaths, suffers from one of the most severe diseases. This is preoccupation with what does not concern him and heedlessness toward his own soul (النفس). The soul stores this information during the time of friendship for a future day, and he is unaware of it, being veiled from this awareness by his current affection for the friend. If he finds the slightest dislike for his companion in his soul, or symptoms of boredom, or a slip (هفوة) committed against him, he brings out what was stored of the ugly things that were hidden with him and which he had kept for him in his soul during his tracking. He says to him in the context of reproach: "Did you not say such-and-such on such-and-such a day? Did you not do such-and-such on such-and-such a day?" Then, when he enumerates what he had stored, he says to him: "All this indicates a lack of religion or no religion at all. I saw all this in you and said, 'Perhaps he has some justification for it,' but you have no justification for it in the Sacred Law (الشرع)." This is contrary to the Real (الحق). He makes him hear what he dislikes, what he was heedless of, and what he did not know that this person was counting against him. He turns into one of his greatest enemies. The root of all this is the tracking of his faults (مثالبه) and storing them in the treasury of his soul, which stems from bad character (سوء الطبع) and baseness of origin and branch. This is often found among companions and friends. It has been said concerning this:

> احذر عدوك مرة *** واحذر صديقك ألف مرة
> فلربما هجر الصديق *** فكان أعرف بالمضرة
> Beware of your enemy once, *** and beware of your friend a thousand times.
> For perhaps the friend will abandon you, *** and he will be more knowledgeable of the harm.

All this is a calamity that returns upon the speaker, even if it is true.

Among the diseases of speech is asking about the affairs of people and what they do: "Why did so-and-so come? Why did so-and-so walk?" and asking about everything that does not concern one, including asking a man about his family and what they did in his absence.

Its remedy is following the example of the Messenger of God (may God bless him and grant him peace) in that he did not approach his family at night upon returning from a journey, and he forbade his companions from doing so, lest they surprise them and see something displeasing. Seeking permission (الاستئذان) falls under this category, in order to maintain concealment (الستر). For it is known that everyone has slips (هنات). Furthermore, not everything a person does, even if it is good, does he wish everyone to know about. If this questioner insists on knowing, he harms the one being questioned, forcing him either to speak what he does not wish or to lie. If he does not speak, it leaves a sting (خرازة) in the questioner's soul, who says, "If I held a high status with him, he would not have concealed what I asked about," thus diminishing the sincerity of the affection he held for him. Even if he harbors a suspicion that leads him to such an action, he is not permitted to do so by Sacred Law (شرعا), intellect (عقلا), or chivalry (مروءة). This is a matter that rarely occurs except from one whose inner self (الباطن) is corrupt, who lacks religion, and whose inner disposition (السريرة) is evil.

The Prophet (may God bless him and grant him peace) said: "Part of the excellence of a man's Islam is his leaving alone that which does not concern him."

Among the diseases of speech is conferring favors (الامتنان) and speaking about the good one does for a person by way of reminding him of the favor (المن), and reminding of a favor is harm (الأذى). Its remedy is that since this displeases him and nullifies the reward of the Lord of the favor (رب النعمة). Indeed, God Almighty has invalidated that action with His saying: <<لا تُبْطِلُوا صَدَقاتِكُمْ بِالْمَنِّ والْأَذى>> (Do not nullify your charities by reminders of favor or injury). And what harm is greater than reminding of a favor, for it is psychological harm (أذى نفسي). Its remedy is that he should not see that what reached him from what was in his hands is anything other than what was destined for him in God's Knowledge (علم الله). That good deed was merely a trust (أمانة) in his hand; it was not his, but he did not know its owner. When he gave it out to the one God designated in the reality of the matter (في نفس الأمر), he then recognized the owner of that trust, and he thanked God for fulfilling it. Whoever is granted this perspective can never genuinely remind others of a favor.

Another disease of speech is when a man does good for some of his children due to an internal motive, but does not do that good for others. Then someone says to him, in the presence of the child who did not receive the favor, "Why did you not do the same for this other child?" This is superfluous speech (فضول الكلام) since it was said in the presence of the child, and it yields enmity toward his father in the child's soul. Such a thing only occurs from an ignorant person (جاهل) who is excessively meddlesome (كثير الفضول), for it is a satanic word. There is no remedy for it after it occurs. But before it occurs, its remedy is to consider:

The saying of the Prophet (may God bless him and grant him peace): "Part of the excellence of a man's Islam is his leaving alone that which does not concern him."

Another disease of speech is when a person says, "I speak the truth and I do not care whether it is difficult for the listener or not," without considering the superfluity of the speech or its proper context. Then he says, "I told so-and-so the truth, and it was difficult for him to hear," thereby praising himself and criticizing others. He forgets the saying of God Almighty: <<لا خَيْرَ في كَثِيرٍ من نَجْواهُمْ>> (There is no good in much of their private conversation). This is the remedy for this ailment. The remedy is: <<لا خَيْرَ في كَثِيرٍ من نَجْواهُمْ إِلَّا من أَمَرَ بِصَدَقَةٍ>> (There is no good in much of their private conversation, except for one who enjoins charity). And this has specific contexts and descriptions: that he enjoins it secretly, not openly, for openness is an ailment of which he may be unaware, as he might give it for other than God. Then He said: <<أَوْ مَعْرُوفٍ>> (or good conduct). Speaking good conduct (قول المعروف) means speaking in the context designated by God, hoping for benefit for the listener. This is the meaning of "or good conduct." Whoever fails to do this is ignorant, even if he claims knowledge. Then He said: <<أَوْ إِصْلاحٍ بَيْنَ النَّاسِ>> (or reconciliation between people). He knows that God's intent is mutual affection and love, so he strives for that. If he does not place the speech in its proper context, it leads to severance, aversion, and turning away. Then, after all this, He spoke concerning the speaker: "And whoever does this seeking the pleasure of God." This can only be done by one who knows what pleases God. And one only knows what pleases God through knowledge of what God has legislated in His Book and upon the tongue of His Messenger. Thus, when he intends to speak about a matter, he considers whether his utterance in that context pleases God in all respects. If he finds any aspect that compromises it, the whole is unacceptable and displeasing to God, for it does not tolerate fragmentation or division. This is a point of error, and its remedy is what we have stated: the prescribed action (العمل المشروع) and the knowledge (العلم) of what pleases God.

Another disease of speech is changing the reprehensible (المنكر) directed at a specific person, whether a ruler or otherwise, without generalizing. Its remedy is knowing the balance (الميزان) in this matter and being free in his own soul from every reprehensible act that he knows the Sacred Law (الشرع) condemns according to his own school (مذهبه) and independent judgment (اجتهاده), and nothing else. He is not bound by what is reprehensible to others but permissible to him. Then, regarding what is reprehensible to him, he looks at whom he is changing it upon. If it is someone who holds it to be permissible—like date-wine (النبيذ) for a Hanafi, if he sees him drinking it or performing ablution with it, while it is forbidden to him—he should only change it upon those who specifically believe it to be forbidden, or if it is a reprehensible act upon which there is consensus. This is the balance (الميزان).

The ramifications of speech are numerous. The summary of its ailments and remedies lies in two matters: First, that you speak when you desire to be silent, and you are silent when you desire to speak. Second, that you do not speak except concerning that which, if you remained silent about it, you would be disobedient (عاصيا); otherwise, do not speak. Beware of speaking when you find your speech pleasing and sweet, for speech at that time is one of the greatest diseases, and its only remedy is silence, unless you are witnessing the lifting of the veil (رفع الستر). This is the governing principle (الضابط).

(Section) As for the diseases of actions (الأفعال), it is when your performance of an act of worship, such as prayer (الصلاة), is better in public (في الملإ) than your performance of it in private (في السر). The Prophet (may God bless him and grant him peace) said concerning such an action: "That is a slighting by which he slighted his Lord," referring to a man who perfected his prayer in public but performed it poorly in private (الخلوة). This is one of the most difficult psychological diseases. Its remedy is: <<أَ لَمْ يَعْلَمْ بِأَنَّ الله يَرى>> (Does he not know that Allah sees?) and (He) <<يَعْلَمُ سِرَّكُمْ وجَهْرَكُمْ>> (knows your secret and your open speech). And God is more worthy of being shy before. And similar verses and narrations. It has another remedy, but its composition is subtle: that he intends by perfecting his action to teach the ignorant and remind the heedless. Also among the diseases of action is abandoning action for the sake of people, which is hypocrisy (الرياء) according to the general consensus. As for acting *for* the sake of people, that is polytheism (شرك), not hypocrisy, according to the Masters (السادة) among the People of God (أهل الله). Its remedy is: <<والله خَلَقَكُمْ وما تَعْمَلُونَ>> (And Allah created you and what you do), and similar verses. Know this.

(Section) As for the diseases of spiritual states (الأحوال), it is associating with the righteous (الصالحين) until he becomes famous among people as one of them, while inwardly he is still attached to his desires (شهوته). If they attend a spiritual concert (سماع) and he is in love with a girl or a boy, and the group is unaware of this, he is overcome by ecstasy (وجد) and the spiritual state (الحال) dominates him due to his attachment to that person in his soul. He moves, cries out, sighs deeply, and says "Allah, Allah" or "He is He," and makes the gestures of the People of God (أهل الله). The group believes his state is a divine state, even though he possesses genuine ecstasy (وجد صحيح) and a genuine state (حال صحيحة), but it is directed toward *whom*? Its remedy is: <<وَقَدْ خابَ مَنْ دَسَّاها>> (And he has failed who covered it [the soul] with corruption), and similar narrations. Another disease of spiritual states is that he wears less than what is in his soul. Its remedy is that he wears what is in his soul, provided it is permissible for him to wear. And similar matters. Whoever knows these ailments and their remedies and applies them to himself will benefit.

(It is narrated) concerning Shaykh Ruzbihan that he was afflicted by the love of a singing woman and was passionately devoted to her (هام فيها وجدا). He used to shout frequently during his state of ecstasy (وجد) in God, to the extent that he disturbed those circumambulating the Kaaba during his stay there. He used to circumambulate on the roofs of the Sanctuary. He was sincere in his state (صادق الحال). When he was afflicted by the love of this singer, no one noticed, and the ruling of what he had with God transferred to her. He knew that people imagined that his ecstasy was for God, based on his original state. So he came to the Sufis, took off the patched cloak (الخرقة), threw it to them, told people his story, and said, "I do not wish to lie about my state (حالي)." He then devoted himself to serving the singer. The woman was informed of his condition and his devotion to her, and that he was one of the great People of God (أهل الله). The woman felt shame, repented to God from what she was doing, and devoted herself to his service. God removed that attachment to her from his heart. He then returned to the Sufis and wore his patched cloak, having refused to lie to God about his state. This is how sincere they are.

This is the summary of the matter, for a human being is inevitably established in speech, action, or state, and there is no fourth. Likewise, the one who stands up during a state of ecstasy (وجد)—if the ecstasy leaves him, he sits down immediately and does not feign ecstasy (يتواجد). If he feigns ecstasy and does not tell those present that he is feigning, he is afflicted with a disease. This is the comprehensive summary of this issue. The ramifications of speech, actions, and states are numerous. Let one beware of lying in this regard and adhere to sincerity (الصدق). He should not manifest to people except what he manifests to God in the appropriate context. For knowledge (العلم) of God's ruling (حكم الله) in the details of these matters is a prerequisite for the People of God (أهل الله), and it is indispensable. God is not worshipped by one who does not know His ruling, for God has never taken an ignorant person as a saint (ولي).

We have now mentioned the comprehensive chapters and sections of Gnosis (المعرفة), which, if attained by a person, qualify him specifically as a Gnostic (عارف). If he adds to this the Knowledge (العلم) of God, what is necessary for Him, what is permissible for Him, and what is impossible for Him, and distinguishes between his knowledge of His Essence (ذاته) and his knowledge of His being a God (إلها)—this is the station (مقام) of the Scholars of God (العلماء بالله), not the station of the Gnostics (العارفين). For Gnosis (المعرفة) is a clear path and a way, while Knowledge (العلم) is a proof. Knowledge is a Divine Attribute (نعت إلهي), whereas Gnosis is an existential, psychic, Lordly Attribute (نعت كياني نفسي رباني). This chapter is dedicated to Gnosis. However, our companions among the People of God have applied the name Gnostics (العارفين) to the Scholars of God, and they call the Knowledge of God attained through direct experience (الذوق) Gnosis (معرفة), unifying this station by its results and necessary consequences that manifest from this attribute in its possessors.

Junayd was asked about Gnosis and the Gnostic. He replied: "The color of the water is the color of its container." Meaning, he is characterized by the morals of God (أخلاق الله) to the extent that he is as if He, yet he is not He, and He is He. The Gnostic (العارف), according to the consensus, is one who instills in his soul awe (الهيبة), tranquility (السكينة), and the absence of distracting attachments. He makes the beginning of Gnosis for God and its end that which is endless. No truth or falsehood enters his heart. Gnosis necessitates his absence from his own self (الغيبة عن نفسه) due to the dominance of the remembrance of the Real (ذكر الحق). Thus, he witnesses none but God and returns to none other. He lives by his Lord, not by his heart. And Gnosis, when it enters his heart, corrupts the spiritual states (أحواله) he was upon, by turning them toward God Almighty, not by annihilating them. For, according to them, it is as God Almighty said, quoting Bilqis: <<إِنَّ الْمُلُوكَ إِذا دَخَلُوا قَرْيَةً أَفْسَدُوها وجَعَلُوا أَعِزَّةَ أَهْلِها أَذِلَّةً وكَذلِكَ يَفْعَلُونَ>> (Indeed, when kings enter a city, they corrupt it and make the honored ones of its people the most humbled. And thus they do). But according to us, it is not so. Rather, they make the honored ones of its people honored *by God* after they were honored by other than God, and their humiliation is *for God*, not for other than God. Thus, the Gnostic has no state (حال) with them due to the effacement of his traces, the annihilation (فناء) of his identity (هويته), and the absence of his effect. And Gnosis is not sound while the servant possesses self-sufficiency *from* God.

The Gnostic is mute, severed, cut off, subdued, incapable of praising the One known (معروفه). He is fearful and weary of remaining in this physical structure, even if it is illuminated, because the Lawgiver (الشارع) informed him that in death is the meeting with God (لقاء الله). Thus, the life of this world is spoiled for him out of longing for that meeting. His life is pure, yet troubled; good in the reality of the matter (في نفس الأمر), but not in his own self. Every created thing has departed from him, and every observer holds him in awe; when he is seen, God is remembered.

He possesses intimacy (أنس) with God, and he is with God without separation (فصل) or connection (وصل). Reverence (تعظيم) lives in his heart. His heart is a mirror (مرآة) for the Real (الحق). He is forbearing, enduring, empty of this world and the Hereafter. He possesses astonishment (دهش) and bewilderment (حيرة). He takes his actions from God and returns to God concerning them. His belly is hungry, and his body is bare. He does not grieve over anything, for he sees none but God. He is a flyer; his eye weeps, and his heart laughs. He is like the earth, trodden upon by the righteous and the wicked; like the cloud, shading everything; and like the rain, watering what is loved and what is not loved. He has no distinction (تمييز). He does not satisfy his need from anything. His weeping is over himself, and his praise is for his Lord. He wastes his wealth and stands with what belongs to the Real (الحق); he is not distracted from Him for the blink of an eye. He knows his Lord by his Lord. He is guided in his spiritual states (أحواله). Others (الأغيار) do not perceive him. He speaks nothing but the speech of God. He is alienated (مستوحش) from creation. He possesses poverty (فقر) and lowliness (ذلة) that bequeath richness and might. His Gnosis (معرفته) is the rising of the Real upon the secrets (الأسرار) and the continuous connection of the lights (الأنوار). His state (حال) is above what he says. The states are equal for him in the opening (الفتح); revelation opens for him on his bed just as it opens for him in his prayer, even if the incoming inspirations (الواردات) differ according to the contexts. He is constant in remembrance (الذكر). He possesses flashes (لوامع) that abolish distinction (التمييز). Nothing troubles him, and everything is purified by him. Various types of Knowledge (العلم) illuminate for him, by which he perceives the wonders of the Unseen (الغيب). He is consumed in the seas of verification (التحقيق). He is the master of waves that submerge and then lift and then lower. He is the master of the moment (وقت) and the complete fulfillment of the rights of the Divine Ordinances (المراسم الإلهية). His description in his transformation from one attribute to another is constant; he neither forces nor attracts. He is the unique one of the moment (أحيد الوقت). He encompasses things, but they do not encompass him. He hopes, but is not hoped for. He is merciful, intimate, witnessing the Majesty of the Real (جلال الحق) and the Beauty of the Presence (جمال الحضرة). He is receptive to every incoming inspiration (وارد). He encounters matters without intention. He has existence (وجود) in the very eye of loss (فقد). He possesses severity (قهر) in gentleness (لطف) and gentleness in severity. He is the Real (حق) without creation (خلق). He witnesses God's Sustaining (قيام الله) over everything. He is absent from Him by Him, subsisting with Him by Him. Absent from formation (التكوين), present with the Former (المكون). Sober by others, intoxicated by His love. He is the collector of the Theophany (التجلي); what has passed does not escape him by virtue of what he is in. He is constant in connection, perfecting worship (العبادة) in custom while removing ailments. He is inherently obedient, accepting the command of his Lord, transcendent beyond resemblance (منزه عن الشبيه). The rulings of the Sacred Law (أحكام الشرع) apply to him in the very eye of the Reality (الحقيقة). He possesses spirit (روح) and fragrance (ريحان). His heart is a beaten path (طريق مطرقة) for every seeker (سالك). He is the master of guidance (دليل), unveiling (كشف), and witnessing (شهود). He honors the incoming inspiration (الوارد) and behaves courteously with the witness (الشاهد). He is free from ailments. He is the master of inspiration (إلقاء) and reception (تلق). He is guarded, concealed by his passionate love (ولهه), imprisoned in the station (الموقف), passing away under compulsion (القهر). His return is spiritual journeying (سلوك), and his veil is witnessing (شهود). The secret (سرّه) of his core is not known by his core. Whenever a face (وجه) is revealed to him, he knows that a face has been concealed from him. He is singular without singularity, with successive states (متواتر الأحوال) by the ruling of the Names (الأسماء). Trustworthy in understanding, capable of increase, unifying multiplicity (الكثرة). He is the master of ancient discourse (حديث قديم). He knows what is behind the veils without the lifting of a veil. He possesses an effacing light (نور طامس); its rays are burning, and the suddenness of its incoming inspirations (وارداته) is disturbing. What he does not know is returned to him. He is established in his transformation (تلوينه), because his Creator is every day in a [new] affair. He is entirely stripped of other-than-God (السوي). He stands with the Real (الحق) in His context. He desires everything that is desired from him. He possesses Divine Providence (عناية إلهية) that attracts him. He is a traveler (سالك) in stillness, a resident in his journey. He is the master of insight (نظرة) and contemplation (نظر). He finds what expression cannot encompass of the subtleties of understanding (دقائق الفهوم) from God, without cause. He is refined in character, not affirming incarnation (الاتحاد). He travels in every school of thought without traveling. His spirit (الروح) is sanctified from the arrogance of the souls (رعونات النفوس). His levels (المراتب) are known in the carpet (البساط). He believes in the Speaker (الناطق) in his secret, listening to Him, desiring what He wills for him, compassionate toward what is in his inner self. He manifests the opposite of what is hidden for the benefit of his moment. His passionate love (ولهه) does not rule him. He is a stranger in the Highest and Lowest Assembly (الملإ الأعلى والأسفل). He possesses an active, restricted, not absolute, aspiration (همة فعالة مقيدة غير مطلقة). He is jealous over the secrets (الأسرار) lest they be divulged. Nothing enslaves him. He observes the existents (الكوائن) by way of consultation, seeking clarification in that which he finds. This prevents him from agitation, because the station of existence does not necessitate it for him. He possesses the totality of goodness. He governs by the Will (المشيئة), not by the Name (الاسم). His two ends are equal, so his beginning (أزله) is like his eternity (أبده). The stations (المقامات) revolve around him, but he does not revolve around them. He has two hands with which he grasps and extends in the world of the Unseen (الغيب) and the Visible (الشهادة) by the command of the Real (الحق), possessing vicegerency (خلافة) and sainthood (ولاية). He is the bearer of the burdens of the Kingdom. Hidden matters are extracted through him. He creates his thoughts as persons in his own image. He is protected in the four directions. He is unique in contemplation. His signs in the Kingdom (الملكوت) are witnessed events. The attributes of the Gnostic are too numerous to count. These are some indications of the Sufi community (الطائفة) concerning the reality of the Gnostic (العارف) and Gnosis (المعرفة). We have brought them so that we may know their intentions in this, lest anyone say that we have isolated ourselves on a path they did not traverse. Rather, the Path is one, even if every person has a specific path. For the paths to God Almighty are equal to the number of the breaths of creation (أنفاس الخلائق). Meaning, every breath is a path to God, and this is true. To the extent that you miss the knowledge of the breaths and their observance, you miss the knowledge of the Path. And to the extent that you miss the knowledge of the paths, you miss their goals. And the goal of every path is God, for <<إِلَيْهِ يُرْجَعُ الْأَمْرُ كُلُّهُ>> (To Him all matters are returned).

As for the description of the Gnostic (العارف) according to us, from the Divine Context (الموطن الإلهي) that the Gnostics witness from the Real (الحق) in their existence (وجودهم)—and this is a rare witnessing (شهود عزيز)—it is that the Gnostic, when Gnosis is attained by him, stands with the Real (الحق) in his totality (جمعية), penetrating in aspiration (نافذ الهمة), influencing Existence (الوجود) absolutely, without restriction, but according to the balance (الميزان) known to the People of God (أهل الله). He is unknown in description and attribute to others among all creation: humans, jinn, angels, and animals. He is not known so as to be defined, nor does he depart from custom so as to be distinguished. He is the bearer of remembrance (الذكر), concealed in his state (حال), universal in compassion (شفقة) toward God's servants. In his mercy, he distinguishes between those whom he is commanded to show mercy to, so that he assigns a specific description to him. He is a Gnostic of the Will of the Real (إرادة الحق) concerning His servants before the willed thing occurs, so he wills by the Will of the Real. He neither contends nor resists. Nothing occurs in Existence that he does not will, even if what occurs is something he does not approve of, but rather dislikes. He is severe in gentleness. He knows the noble traits of character (مكارم الأخلاق) even in their trivialities, placing them in their proper stations with their people, a placement of wisdom. He is innocent of those whom God has declared innocent, yet he is kind to them despite his innocence of them. He affirms every report in the world; what others know to be a lie is truth to him. He grants security to God's servants from his own deceptions. He witnesses the glorification (تسبيح) of creatures in the variety of their remembrances, which is not revealed except to a Gnostic like him. When the Real (الحق) discloses Himself (تجلى) to him, he says, "I am He," due to the strength of resemblance in the universality of the cosmic and Divine Attributes. If he says *Bismillah* (In the Name of God), everything he intended with his aspiration (همة) comes into being from that utterance. He does not say "Be!" out of courtesy (أدبا) toward God. He gives contexts their due: great by the Real, small for the Real, moderate with the Real. He combines these attributes in a single state. He is knowledgeable of measures (المقادير) and balances (الأوزان); he neither exceeds nor falls short. He is affected with deliberation by the change of states, so nothing escapes him from the world, nor from what the Real is upon in the moment, of what the world seeks in the time of the state. He witnesses the origination of forms (الصور) from his breaths, in the image of what is in his heart when the breath exits. If an unfamiliar breath enters him from outside to cool the heart, he bestows upon that breath the robe of the moment (خلعة الوقت), and that breath is dyed by the light he finds in the heart. He conceals his station (مقام) by his state (حال), and his state by his station. Thus, the people of states are ignorant of his station, and the people of stations are ignorant of his state. He is severe toward his desire (شهوته) if he does not see the Face of the Real (وجه الحق) in its nature. He gives his gift for you, not for himself. His giving is unmotivated. He does not remind of a favor when he confers one, but he reminds of the favor of accepting the favor. He does not hold the ignorant person accountable for his ignorance, for his ignorance has a face in Knowledge (العلم). He does not make the recipient aware, when he gives, that it is a trust (أمانة) with him that he was commanded to deliver to him; nor does he make him aware that it is from God. He opens the locks of difficult matters with the manifest light (النور المبين). He eats from above him and from beneath his foot. He draws hearts to himself when he wills, without them realizing it, and sends them away when he wills, without them realizing it. He possesses the reins of matters, and they possess him, by virtue of the Face of the Real (وجه الحق) and nothing else. He looks toward the high and descends with his gaze, and he looks toward the low and ascends and rises with his gaze. He restricts the expansive and expands the restricted. He hears every audible thing from Him, not from the perspective of that audible thing, and he sees every visible thing from Him, not from the perspective of that visible thing. He judges between two disputants in a way that satisfies both, ruling for each one, not against him, despite the contradiction of the matter. He inclines toward a path other than his own path, within his path, due to the wisdom of the moment (حكمة الوقت). The remembrance of the soul (ذكر النفس) prevails over the remembrance of the assembly (ذكر الملإ) for the sake of comparison, out of jealousy that the Real should be compared, for he is a rememberer by the Real, in the Real. All matters are experiential (ذوقية) to him, not merely informative (خبرية). He knows his Lord from himself, just as the Real knows the cosmos from His knowledge of Himself. He does not hold accountable for a crime, for the crime is a deserved consequence, and the deserving criminal's greatness lies in his lowliness and smallness. He does not depart from his lowliness in the context of his greatness, neither in this world nor the Hereafter. He is in his knowledge according to his knowledge: if action is required, he acts; if non-action is required, he does not act. The treasuries of matters are with him by his ruling, and their keys are in his hand. He descends as much as he wills and brings forth what he wills without awareness. He is a diver into the subtleties of understanding (دقائق الفهوم) when expressions arrive. He possesses the attributes of perfection. He holds the station of the Five (مقام الخمسة) in protecting himself and others. He looks at the saying: <<أَعْطى‏ كُلَّ شَيْ‏ءٍ خَلْقَهُ>> (He gave everything its creation), and does not transgress it. He manages the affairs of the cosmos between himself and his Lord, like a knowledgeable, sincere advisor in service, upholding reverence. There is no 'where-ness' (أينية) to his secret. He is not stingy when asked. He looks at the Divine Traces (الآثار الإلهية) existing in the cosmos to compare them with what he possesses, having heard God say: <<سَنُرِيهِمْ آياتِنا في الْآفاقِ وفي أَنْفُسِهِمْ>> (We will show them Our signs in the horizons and within themselves). He hears the call of the Real (نداء الحق) from the tongues of creation. He encompasses things, but nothing encompasses him except his Lord, so he is His son and His eye. He is the organizer of the Divine Commands (الأوامر الإلهية) arriving in the cosmos. He is firm in times of agitation; events do not shake him. There is no attribute in the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) that he does not see in himself. He manifests in whatever form he wills, with the attribute of life, while standing at the boundary. He knows his right from the right of his Creator. He acts in things by deservedness (الاستحقاق), and the Real acts in them through his vicegerency (الاستخلاف). He possesses Divine Power (الاقتدار الإلهي) without struggle. The aspirations of men do not penetrate him, nor does the Real have a right against him. He manages matters by himself, not by his Lord, because he does not see himself due to his Lord's dominance over him. The attributes of transcendence (التنزيه) return to him alongside the existence of resemblance (التشبيه). He counts his breaths by witnessing their forms, knowing what increased and what decreased every day and night. He looks at the Beginning (المبدأ) and the Return (المعاد) and sees the meeting of the two ends of the circle. He casts the Word (الكلمة) into the receptive place, and it changes its form and state, whatever form it was in. He does not tread upon a place except that place is revived by his treading, because he treads upon it with a spiritual life. When he stands, he stands for his Lord's standing, and he is angry for His anger, and pleased for His pleasure. Since his state in his spiritual journeying (سلوك) was thus, it returned to him: <<هَلْ جَزاءُ الْإِحْسانِ إِلَّا الْإِحْسانُ>> (Is the reward for good anything but good?). No thought (خاطر) occurs to him concerning anything except that it comes into being, and that thing does not know that he brought it into being. He possesses the honor of the Cloud (العماء) over things, not the honor of equilibrium (الاستواء). He is unique in the cosmos, his essence (العين) unknown. Whoever seeks refuge in him loses. His need is not fulfilled except through Him, for he appears in the form of incapacity, and his power is behind that incapacity. The possible (ممكن) is not withheld from his power, just as the impossible (محال) is not withheld from the power of his Creator, so that distinction (الامتياز) may be sound. Thus, although he is outwardly delayed, he is inwardly advanced, so that he may combine in his witnessing the First (الأول) and the Last (الآخر), the Inner (الباطن) and the Outer (الظاهر). He is kind to the wrongdoer and the righteous. He returns to God in every matter and does not take revenge for himself or his Lord except by His specific command. If He does not command him, he pardons by right, due to his previous witnessings in the state. The little is much to him, and the much is little to him. He flows with the interests, so the Real (الحق) becomes a king for him. He glorifies the Names of God (أسماء الله) by transcending them from being reached by the hands of the heedless, out of jealousy for the Divine Presence (الجناب الإلهي), in that they are indications of Him, like the indication of the Name upon the Named. If he assumes a position, he grants elevation, yet he does not see himself as exalted by God, much less by himself. He judges justly and is not characterized by oppression. He gathers the sciences of the Sacred Law (علوم الشرع) from the very eye of Collection (عين الجمع). He is self-sufficient from the teaching of creatures by the teaching of the Real. He gives what results in benefit and does not give what results in harm. If he punishes, it is purification. With the light of his justice, there remains no darkness of tyranny, nor with the light of his knowledge, any darkness of ignorance. He explains matters with a Divine tongue, uncovering their obscurity and clarifying them in their context. He invents from the witnessing of an existent form, not from himself. This is not for every Gnostic, but only for one who knows the expenditures (المصارف), for it is a guarded witnessing (مشهد ضنين). He possesses subsistence (البقاء) in transformation (التلوين). He inherits but is not inherited from, by virtue of the general prophecy (النبوة العامة). He acts and does what is appropriate, as appropriate, for what is appropriate. He is harmed, yet he forbears out of capability. If he takes retribution, his grasp is severe, because he is pure, unmixed with mercy. Abu Yazid said, "My grasp is more severe." This is the description of the Gnostic according to me, so verify it, for the context of this acquisition is rare. And God is <<ذُو الْفَضْلِ الْعَظِيمِ>> (Possessor of Great Bounty).

(Section) Concerning the naming of this station as Gnosis (المعرفة) and its possessor as the Gnostic (العارف).
